chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called LSASS Memory. Their names are as follows:
* SILENTTRINITY
* LaZagne
* Lslsass
* Impacket
* Pupy
* PoshC2
* Windows Credential Editor
* Mimikatz
* Empire
* PowerSploit

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LaZagne
Software description: [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is a post-exploitation, open-source tool used to recover stored passwords on a system. It has modules for Windows, Linux, and OSX, but is mainly focused on Windows systems. [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) is publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: GitHub LaZagne Dec 2018)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Lslsass
Software description: [Lslsass](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0121) is a publicly-available tool that can dump active logon session password hashes from the lsass process. (Citation: Mandiant APT1)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Impacket
Software description: [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols. [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) contains several tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.(Citation: Impacket Tools)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: PoshC2
Software description: [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. The server-side components of the tool are primarily written in Python, while the implants are written in [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001). Although [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is primarily focused on Windows implantation, it does contain a basic Python dropper for Linux/macOS.(Citation: GitHub PoshC2)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Windows Credential Editor
Software description: [Windows Credential Editor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0005) is a password dumping tool. (Citation: Amplia WCE)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Mimikatz
Software description: [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) is a credential dumper capable of obtaining plaintext Windows account logins and passwords, along with many other features that make it useful for testing the security of networks. (Citation: Deply Mimikatz) (Citation: Adsecurity Mimikatz Guide)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShell

entities.description: SILENTTRINITY is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. It was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.

entities.name: LAZAGNE
entities.description: LaZagne is a post-exploitation, open-source tool used to recover stored passwords on a system, mainly focused on Windows systems but has modules for Linux and OSX.

entities.name: LSLSASS
entities.description: Lslsass is a publicly-available tool that can dump active logon session password hashes from the lsass process.

entities.name: IMPACKET
entities.description: Impacket is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols, containing tools for remote service execution and credential dumping.

entities.name: PUPY
entities.description: Pupy is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation tool written in Python, capable of being generated as various payloads.

entities.name: POSHC2
entities.description: PoshC2 is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework, primarily focused on Windows implantation but also supports Linux/macOS.

entities.name: WINDOWS CREDENTIAL EDITOR
entities.description: Windows Credential Editor is a password dumping tool used for extracting credentials from Windows systems.

entities.name: MIKATKAZ
entities.description: Mimikatz is a credential dumper capable of obtaining plaintext Windows account logins and passwords, useful for testing network security.

entities.name: EMPIRE
entities.description: Empire is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework, primarily written in Python with post-exploitation agents in PowerShell and Python.

entities.name: POWERSPOILT
entities.description: PowerSploit is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of PowerShell modules and scripts for penetration testing tasks.

Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: POWERSPLIT
entities.description: PowerSploit is an open source, offensive security framework that includes PowerShell modules and scripts for penetration testing tasks.

entities.name: POWERSHELL
entities.description: PowerShell is a task automation framework that includes a command-line shell and associated scripting language, used in conjunction with PowerSploit.

entities.name: GITHUB
entities.description: GitHub is a platform where PowerSploit's source code is hosted and shared, facilitating collaboration and version control.

entities.name: POWERSHELLMAGAZINE
entities.description: PowerShell Magazine is a publication that has featured articles about PowerSploit, providing insights and updates on its usage.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is the operating system platform on which PowerSploit is designed to operate.

entities.name: CODE EXECUTION
entities.description: Code execution refers to the process of running code on a system, which is one of the tasks that PowerSploit can perform during penetration testing.

entities.name: PERSISTENCE
entities.description: Persistence is a technique used to maintain access to a system across reboots, which is a capability provided by PowerSploit.

entities.name: BYPASSING ANTI-VIRUS
entities.description: Bypassing anti-virus refers to techniques used to evade detection by security software, which is a function of PowerSploit.

entities.name: RECON
entities.description: Reconnaissance (recon) is the process of gathering information about a target system, which is a critical step in penetration testing and is supported by PowerSploit.

entities.name: EXFILTRATION
entities.description: Exfiltration is the unauthorized transfer of data from a computer, which is one of the tasks that PowerSploit can perform during penetration testing.

There are 10 software using the attack technique called Service Stop. Their names are as follows:
* Clop
* LookBack
* Meteor
* WannaCry
* Royal
* Diavol
* Avaddon
* Olympic Destroyer
* Cheerscrypt
* Prestige

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Clop
Software description: [Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611) is a ransomware family that was first observed in February 2019 and has been used against retail, transportation and logistics, education, manufacturing, engineering, automotive, energy, financial, aerospace, telecommunications, professional and legal services, healthcare, and high tech industries. [Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611) is a variant of the CryptoMix ransomware.(Citation: Mcafee Clop Aug 2019)(Citation: Cybereason Clop Dec 2020)(Citation: Unit42 Clop April 2021) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LookBack
Software description: [LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582) is a remote access trojan written in C++ that was used against at least three US utility companies in July 2019. The TALONITE activity group has been observed using [LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582).(Citation: Proofpoint LookBack Malware Aug 2019)(Citation: Dragos TALONITE)(Citation: Dragos Threat Report 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Meteor
Software description: [Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) is a wiper that was used against Iranian government organizations, including Iranian Railways, the Ministry of Roads, and Urban Development systems, in July 2021. [Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) is likely a newer version of similar wipers called Stardust and Comet that were reportedly used by a group called "Indra" since at least 2019 against private companies in Syria.(Citation: Check Point Meteor Aug 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: WannaCry
Software description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) is ransomware that was first seen in a global attack during May 2017, which affected more than 150 countries. It contains worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network using the SMBv1 exploit EternalBlue.(Citation: LogRhythm WannaCry)(Citation: US-CERT WannaCry 2017)(Citation: Washington Post WannaCry 2017)(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Royal
Software description: [Royal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1073) is ransomware that first appeared in early 2022;  a version that also targets ESXi servers was later observed in February 2023. [Royal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1073) employs partial encryption and multiple threads to evade detection and speed encryption. [Royal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1073) has been used in attacks against multiple industries worldwide--including critical infrastructure. Security researchers have identified similarities in the encryption routines and TTPs used in [Royal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1073) and [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) attacks and noted a possible connection between their operators.(Citation: Microsoft Royal ransomware November 2022)(Citation: Cybereason Royal December 2022)(Citation: Kroll Royal Deep Dive February 2023)(Citation: Trend Micro Royal Linux ESXi February 2023)(Citation: CISA Royal AA23-061A March 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Diavol
Software description: [Diavol](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0659) is a ransomware variant first observed in June 2021 that is capable of prioritizing file types to encrypt based on a pre-configured list of extensions defined by the attacker.  The [Diavol](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0659) Ransomware-as-a Service (RaaS) program is managed by [Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) and it has been observed being deployed by [Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534).(Citation: Fortinet Diavol July 2021)(Citation: FBI Flash Diavol January 2022)(Citation: DFIR Diavol Ransomware December 2021)(Citation: Microsoft Ransomware as a Service)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Avaddon
Software description: [Avaddon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0640) is ransomware written in C++ that has been offered as Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) since at least June 2020.(Citation: Awake Security Avaddon)(Citation: Arxiv Avaddon Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Olympic Destroyer
Software description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) is malware that was used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) against the 2018 Winter Olympics, held in Pyeongchang, South Korea. The main purpose of the malware was to render infected computer systems in

Platforms: Windows

Software name: Olympic Destroyer
Software description: [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) is malware that was used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) against the 2018 Winter Olympics, held in Pyeongchang, South Korea. The main purpose of the malware was to render infected computer systems inoperable. The malware leverages various native Windows utilities and API calls to carry out its destructive tasks. [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) has worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network in order to maximize its destructive impact.(Citation: Talos Olympic Destroyer 2018)(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Unit 74455 October 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cheerscrypt
Software description: [Cheerscrypt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1096) is a ransomware that was developed by [Cinnamon Tempest](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1021) and has been used in attacks against ESXi and Windows environments since at least 2022. [Cheerscrypt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1096) was derived from the leaked [Babuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0638) source code and has infrastructure overlaps with deployments of Night Sky ransomware, which was also derived from [Babuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0638).(Citation: Sygnia Emperor Dragonfly October 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Cheerscrypt May 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Prestige
Software description: [Prestige](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1058) ransomware has been used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) since at least March 2022, including against transportation and related logistics industries in Ukraine and Poland in October 2022.(Citation: Microsoft Prestige ransomware October 2022)
Platforms: Windows

There are 10 software using the attack technique called Encrypted/Encoded File. Their names are as follows:
* PcShare
* Sliver
* IronNetInjector
* DEADEYE
* Torisma
* OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
* USBStealer
* Emissary
* Kessel
* Raindrop

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: PcShare
Software description: [PcShare](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1050) is an open source remote access tool that has been modified and used by Chinese threat actors, most notably during the FunnyDream campaign since late 2018.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)(Citation: GitHub PcShare 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Sliver
Software description: [Sliver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0633) is an open source, cross-platform, red team command and control framework written in Golang.(Citation: Bishop Fox Sliver Framework August 2019)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: IronNetInjector
Software description: [IronNetInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0581) is a [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolchain that utilizes scripts from the open-source IronPython implementation of Python with a .NET injector to drop one or more payloads including [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126).(Citation: Unit 42 IronNetInjector February 2021 )
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DEADEYE
Software description: [DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) is a malware launcher that has been used by [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) since at least May 2021. [DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) has variants that can either embed a payload inside a compiled binary (DEADEYE.EMBED) or append it to the end of a file (DEADEYE.APPEND).(Citation: Mandiant APT41)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Torisma
Software description: [Torisma](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0678) is a second stage implant designed for specialized monitoring that has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032). [Torisma](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0678) was discovered during an investigation into the 2020 Operation North Star campaign that targeted the defense sector.(Citation: McAfee Lazarus Nov 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Software description: [OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) is a macOS backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050). First discovered in 2015, [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has continued to make improvements using a plugin architecture to extend capabilities, specifically using `.dylib` files. [OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) can also determine it's permission level and execute according to access type (`root` or `user`).(Citation: Unit42 OceanLotus 2017)(Citation: TrendMicro MacOS April 2018)(Citation: Trend Micro MacOS Backdoor November 2020)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: USBStealer
Software description: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) is malware that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) since at least 2005 to extract information from air-gapped networks. It does not have the capability to communicate over the Internet and has been used in conjunction with [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045). (Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014) (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Emissary
Software description: [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) is a Trojan that has been used by [Lotus Blossom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0030). It shares code with [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081), with both Trojans being part of a malware group referred to as LStudio. (Citation: Lotus Blossom Dec 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Kessel

[Kessel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0487) has been active since its C2 domain began resolving in August 2018.(Citation: ESET ForSSHe December 2018)

entities.description: Sliver is an open source, cross-platform, red team command and control framework written in Golang.

entities.name: IRONNETINJECTOR
entities.description: IronNetInjector is a Turla toolchain that utilizes scripts from the open-source IronPython implementation of Python with a .NET injector to drop payloads.

entities.name: DEADEYE
entities.description: DEADEYE is a malware launcher used by APT41 since at least May 2021, with variants that can embed or append payloads.

entities.name: TORISMA
entities.description: Torisma is a second stage implant designed for specialized monitoring used by the Lazarus Group during the 2020 Operation North Star campaign.

entities.name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
entities.description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D is a macOS backdoor used by APT32, first discovered in 2015, with a plugin architecture to extend capabilities.

entities.name: USBSTEALER
entities.description: USBStealer is malware used by APT28 since at least 2005 to extract information from air-gapped networks.

entities.name: EMISSARY

entities.name: KESSEL
entities.description: Kessel is an advanced version of OpenSSH acting as a custom backdoor to steal credentials and function as a bot.

Software name: Raindrop
Software description: [Raindrop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0565) is a loader used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) that was discovered on some victim machines during investigations related to the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024). It was discovered in January 2021 and was likely used since at least May 2020.(Citation: Symantec RAINDROP January 2021)(Citation: Microsoft Deep Dive Solorigate January 2021)

There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Windows Management Instrumentation. Their names are as follows:
* Privileged Account Management 
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 
* User Account Management 
* Execution Prevention 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT

entities.name: EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description: Execution Prevention is a mitigation method that blocks the execution of code on a system through application control and/or script blocking.

entities.description: Windows Management Instrumentation is an attack technique that can be mitigated through various methods to enhance system security.

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Imminent Monitor
Software description: [Imminent Monitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0434) was a commodity remote access tool (RAT) offered for sale from 2012 until 2019, when an operation was conducted to take down the Imminent Monitor infrastructure. Various cracked versions and variations of this RAT are still in circulation.(Citation: Imminent Unit42 Dec2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Remcos
Software description: [Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) is a closed-source tool that is marketed as a remote control and surveillance software by a company called Breaking Security. [Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) has been observed being used in malware campaigns.(Citation: Riskiq Remcos Jan 2018)(Citation: Talos Remcos Aug 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Flame
Software description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) is a sophisticated toolkit that has been used to collect information since at least 2010, largely targeting Middle East countries. (Citation: Kaspersky Flame)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ROKRAT
Software description: [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) is a cloud-based remote access tool (RAT) used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) to target victims in South Korea. [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has used ROKRAT during several campaigns from 2016 through 2021.(Citation: Talos ROKRAT)(Citation: Talos Group123)(Citation: Volexity InkySquid RokRAT August 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Bandook
Software description: [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) is a commercially available RAT, written in Delphi and C++, that has been available since at least 2007. It has been used against government, financial, energy, healthcare, education, IT, and legal organizations in the US, South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia. [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) has been used by [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070), as well as in a separate campaign referred to as "Operation Manul".(Citation: EFF Manul Aug 2016)(Citation: Lookout Dark Caracal Jan 2018)(Citation: CheckPoint Bandook Nov 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: VERMIN
Software description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) is a remote access tool written in the Microsoft .NET framework. It is mostly composed of original code, but also has some open source code. (Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TajMahal
Software description: [TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) is a multifunctional spying framework that has been in use since at least 2014. [TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) is comprised of two separate packages, named Tokyo and Yokohama, and can deploy up to 80 plugins.(Citation: Kaspersky TajMahal April 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EvilGrab
Software description: [EvilGrab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0152) is a malware family with common reconnaissance capabilities. It has been deployed by [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) via malicious Microsoft Office documents as part of spearphishing campaigns. (Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Scheduled Task. Their names are as follows:
* Privileged Account Management 
* User Account Management 
* Audit 
* Operating System Configuration 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method that makes configuration changes related to the operating system to enhance security against attack techniques.

entities.description: Mitigation Methods refer to the strategies employed to reduce the risk of attack techniques, including Scheduled Task.)<|COMPLETE|>

Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***

Mitigation method name: Pre-compromise

chunk: There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Group Policy Discovery. Their names are as follows: The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows: Attack technique name: *** Attack technique description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target. Attack technique name: Group Policy Discovery Attack technique description: Adversaries may gather information on Group Policy settings to identify paths for privilege escalation, security measures applied within a domain, and to discover patterns in domain objects that can be manipulated or used to blend in the environment. Group Policy allows for centralized management of user and computer settings in Active Directory (AD). Group policy objects (GPOs) are containers for group policy settings made up of files stored within a predictable network path `\\SYSVOL\\Policies\`.(Citation: TechNet Group Policy Basics)(Citation: ADSecurity GPO Persistence 2016) Adversaries may use commands such as gpresult or various publicly available PowerShell functions, such as Get-DomainGPO and Get-DomainGPOLocalGroup, to gather information on Group Policy settings.(Citation: Microsoft gpresult)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire) Adversaries may use this information to shape follow-on behaviors, including determining potential attack paths within the target network as well as opportunities to manipulate Group Policy settings (i.e. [Domain or Tenant Policy Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1484)) for their benefit. Platforms: Windows

entities.name: GROUP POLICY DISCOVERY
entities.description: Group Policy Discovery is an attack technique used by adversaries to gather information on Group Policy settings for privilege escalation and security measures within a domain.

entities.name: ACTIVE DIRECTORY
entities.description: Active Directory is a directory service developed by Microsoft for Windows domain networks, allowing centralized management of user and computer settings.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that can be targeted by the Group Policy Discovery attack technique.

entities.name: PRIVILEGE ESCALATION
entities.description: Privilege Escalation is a type of attack where an adversary gains elevated access to resources that are normally protected from the user.

entities.name: DOMAIN OBJECTS
entities.description: Domain Objects are entities within Active Directory that can be manipulated or used by adversaries to blend into the environment.

entities.name: GPOS
entities.description: Group Policy Objects (GPOs) are containers for Group Policy settings that are stored within a predictable network path and can be targeted by adversaries.

entities.name: GPRESULT
entities.description: gpresult is a command-line tool used to display the Resultant Set of Policy (RSoP) information for a user or computer in a Windows environment.

entities.name: POWERSHELL
entities.description: PowerShell is a task automation framework from Microsoft, consisting of a command-line shell and associated scripting language, which can be used by adversaries to gather information on Group Policy settings.

entities.name: GET-DOMAINGPO
entities.description: Get-DomainGPO is a PowerShell function that retrieves information about Group Policy Objects in a domain.

entities.name: GET-DOMAINGPOLOCALGROUP
entities.description: Get-DomainGPOLocalGroup is a PowerShell function that retrieves information about local Group Policy settings on a computer.

chunk:
There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Email Collection. Their names are as follows:
* Multi-factor Authentication 
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Audit 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Multi-factor Authentication
Mitigation method description: Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: MULTI-FACTOR AUTHENTICATION
entities.description: Multi-factor Authentication is a security method that requires two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system, enhancing security beyond just a username and password.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description: Encrypt Sensitive Information is a method that protects sensitive data through strong encryption techniques to prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a process of performing checks or scans on systems and configurations to identify potential security weaknesses and ensure compliance with security policies.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation Methods refer to strategies and techniques implemented to reduce the risk of attacks, such as Email Collection, by enhancing security measures.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Hidden Window. Their names are as follows:
* Koadic
* SILENTTRINITY
* QuasarRAT
* MCMD
* AsyncRAT
* Astaroth
* QuietSieve
* StrongPity
* Kevin
* HAMMERTOSS

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Koadic
Software description: [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool that is publicly available on GitHub. [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) has several options for staging payloads and creating implants, and performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host.(Citation: Github Koadic)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: MalwareBytes LazyScripter Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QuasarRAT
Software description: [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is an open-source, remote access tool that has been publicly available on GitHub since at least 2014. [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is developed in the C# language.(Citation: GitHub QuasarRAT)(Citation: Volexity Patchwork June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MCMD
Software description: [MCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0500) is a remote access tool that provides remote command shell capability used by [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074).(Citation: Secureworks MCMD July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: AsyncRAT
Software description: [AsyncRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1087) is an open-source remote access tool originally available through the NYANxCAT Github repository that has been used in malicious campaigns.(Citation: Morphisec Snip3 May 2021)(Citation: Cisco Operation Layover September 2021)(Citation: Telefonica Snip3 December 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Astaroth
Software description: [Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) is a Trojan and information stealer known to affect companies in Europe, Brazil, and throughout Latin America. It has been known publicly since at least late 2017. (Citation: Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)(Citation: Cofense Astaroth Sept 2018)(Citation: Securelist Brazilian Banking Malware July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QuietSieve
Software description: [QuietSieve](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0686) is an information stealer that has been used by [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) since at least 2021.(Citation: Microsoft Actinium February 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: StrongPity
Software description: [StrongPity](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0491) is an information stealing malware used by [PROMETHIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0056).(Citation: Bitdefender StrongPity June 2020)(Citation: Talos Promethium June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Kevin
Software description: [Kevin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1020) is a backdoor implant written in C++ that has been used by [HEXANE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1001) since at least June 2020, including in operations against organizations in Tunisia.(Citation: Kaspersky Lyceum October 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HAMMERTOSS
Software description: [HAMMERTOSS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0037) is a backdoor that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) in 2015. (Citation: FireEye APT29) (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: KOADIC
entities.description: Koadic is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool that is publicly available on GitHub, offering various options for staging payloads and creating implants.

entities.name: SILENTTRINITY
entities.description: SILENTTRINITY is an open-source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python, used in cyber campaigns against government agencies.

entities.name: QUASARRAT
entities.description: QuasarRAT is an open-source remote access tool developed in C# and publicly available on GitHub since at least 2014.

entities.name: MCMD
entities.description: MCMD is a remote access tool that provides remote command shell capability, associated with the Dragonfly 2.0 group.

entities.name: ASYNCRAT
entities.description: AsyncRAT is an open-source remote access tool that has been used in various malicious campaigns, originally available through the NYANxCAT GitHub repository.

entities.name: ASTAROTH
entities.description: Astaroth is a Trojan and information stealer known to affect companies in Europe, Brazil, and Latin America, publicly known since at least late 2017.

entities.name: QUIETSIEVE
entities.description: QuietSieve is an information stealer used by the Gamaredon Group since at least 2021.

entities.name: STRONGPITY
entities.description: StrongPity is an information stealing malware used by the PROMETHIUM group.

entities.name: KEVIN
entities.description: Kevin is a backdoor implant written in C++ used by HEXANE since at least June 2020, targeting organizations in Tunisia.

entities.name: HAMMERTOSS
entities.description: HAMMERTOSS is a backdoor used by APT29 in 2015.

chunk:
There are 4 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Gather Victim Host Information. Their names are as follows:
* Hardware
* Firmware
* Software
* Client Configurations

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: Gather Victim Host Information
Attack technique description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's hosts that can be used during targeting. Information about hosts may include a variety of details, including administrative data (ex: name, assigned IP, functionality, etc.) as well as specifics regarding its configuration (ex: operating system, language, etc.).

Adversaries may gather this information in various ways, such as direct collection actions via [Active Scanning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1595) or [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598). Adversaries may also compromise sites then include malicious content designed to collect host information from visitors.(Citation: ATT ScanBox) Information about hosts may also be exposed to adversaries via online or other accessible data sets (ex: [Social Media](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593/001) or [Search Victim-Owned Websites](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1594)). Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587) or [Obtain Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588)), and/or initial access (ex: [Supply Chain Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1195) or [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133)).
Platforms: PRE

Attack technique name: Hardware
Attack technique description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's host hardware that can be used during targeting. Information about hardware infrastructure may include a variety of details such as types and versions on specific hosts, as well as the presence of additional components that might be indicative of added defensive protections (ex: card/biometric readers, dedicated encryption hardware, etc.).

Adversaries may gather this information in various ways, such as direct collection actions via [Active Scanning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1595) (ex: hostnames, server banners, user agent strings) or [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598). Adversaries may also compromise sites then include malicious content designed to collect host information from visitors.(Citation: ATT ScanBox) Information about the hardware infrastructure may also be exposed to adversaries via online or other accessible data sets (ex: job postings, network maps, assessment reports, resumes, or purchase invoices). Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587) or [Obtain Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588)), and/or initial access (ex: [Compromise Hardware Supply Chain](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1195/003) or [Hardware Additions](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1200)).
Platforms: PRE

Attack technique name: Firmware
Attack technique description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's host firmware that can be used during targeting. Information about host firmware may include a variety of details such as type and versions on specific hosts, which may be used to infer more information about hosts in the environment (ex: configuration, purpose, age/patch level, etc.).

Adversaries may gather this information in various ways, such as direct elicitation via [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598). Information about host firmware may only be exposed to adversaries via online or other accessible data sets (ex: job postings, network maps, assessment reports, resumes, or purchase invoices).(Citation: ArsTechnica Intel) Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587) or [Obtain Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588)), and/or initial access (ex: [Supply Chain Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1195) or [Exploit Public-Facing Application](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1190)).
Platforms: PRE

Attack technique name: Software
Attack technique description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's host software that can be used during targeting. Information about installed software may include a variety of details such as types and versions on specific hosts, as well as the presence of additional components that might be indicative of added defensive protections (ex: antivirus, SIEMs, etc.).

entities.name: GATHER VICTIM HOST INFORMATION
entities.description: Gather Victim Host Information is an attack technique used by adversaries to collect information about a victim's hosts for targeting purposes, including administrative data and configuration specifics.

entities.name: HARDWARE
entities.description: Hardware is an attack technique that involves gathering information about the victim's host hardware, including types and versions of specific hosts and additional components that may indicate defensive protections.

entities.name: FIRMWARE
entities.description: Firmware is an attack technique that focuses on gathering information about the victim's host firmware, including types and versions that can provide insights into the hosts' configurations and purposes.

entities.name: SOFTWARE
entities.description: Software is an attack technique that involves collecting information about the victim's installed software, including types and versions, as well as any additional components that may indicate defensive measures.

entities.name: PHISHING FOR INFORMATION
entities.description: Phishing for Information is a technique where adversaries attempt to deceive victims into providing sensitive information, which can be used for targeting.

entities.name: SOCIAL MEDIA
entities.description: Social Media refers to online platforms where users share content and information, which adversaries may exploit to gather data about victims.

entities.name: SEARCH VICTIM-OWNED WEBSITES
entities.description: Search Victim-Owned Websites is a technique used by adversaries to collect information from websites owned by the victim, which may reveal valuable data for targeting.

entities.name: SEARCH OPEN WEBSITES/DOMAINS
entities.description: Search Open Websites/Domains is a reconnaissance technique where adversaries look for publicly available information on websites and domains to gather intelligence.

entities.name: SEARCH OPEN TECHNICAL DATABASES
entities.description: Search Open Technical Databases is a technique used by adversaries to find information in publicly accessible databases that may provide insights into a victim's infrastructure.

entities.name: DEVELOP CAPABILITIES
entities.description: Develop Capabilities is a technique where adversaries establish operational resources to enhance their ability to conduct attacks.

entities.name: OBTAIN CAPABILITIES
entities.description: Obtain Capabilities refers to the process by which adversaries acquire tools, resources, or knowledge necessary for executing attacks.

entities.name: SUPPLY CHAIN COMPROMISE
entities.description: Supply Chain Compromise is a technique where adversaries exploit vulnerabilities in a supply chain to gain access to a target's systems.

entities.name: EXPLOIT PUBLIC-FACING APPLICATION
entities.description: Exploit Public-Facing Application is a technique where adversaries target applications that are accessible over the internet to gain unauthorized access.

Attack technique name: Software
Attack technique description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's host software that can be used during targeting. Information about installed software may include a variety of details such as types and versions on specific hosts, as well as the presence of additional components that might be indicative of added defensive protections (ex: antivirus, SIEMs, etc.).

Adversaries may gather this information in various ways, such as direct collection actions via [Active Scanning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1595) (ex: listening ports, server banners, user agent strings) or [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598). Adversaries may also compromise sites then include malicious content designed to collect host information from visitors.(Citation: ATT ScanBox) Information about the installed software may also be exposed to adversaries via online or other accessible data sets (ex: job postings, network maps, assessment reports, resumes, or purchase invoices). Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587) or [Obtain Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588)), and/or for initial access (ex: [Supply Chain Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1195) or [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133)).
Platforms: PRE

Attack technique name: Client Configurations
Attack technique description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's client configurations that can be used during targeting. Information about client configurations may include a variety of details and settings, including operating system/version, virtualization, architecture (ex: 32 or 64 bit), language, and/or time zone.

Adversaries may gather this information in various ways, such as direct collection actions via [Active Scanning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1595) (ex: listening ports, server banners, user agent strings) or [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598). Adversaries may also compromise sites then include malicious content designed to collect host information from visitors.(Citation: ATT ScanBox) Information about the client configurations may also be exposed to adversaries via online or other accessible data sets (ex: job postings, network maps, assessment reports, resumes, or purchase invoices). Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587) or [Obtain Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588)), and/or initial access (ex: [Supply Chain Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1195) or [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133)).
Platforms: PRE

entities.name: MITRE
entities.description: MITRE is a not-for-profit organization that operates Federally Funded Research and Development Centers (FFRDCs) and provides technical expertise to the U.S. government in various areas, including cybersecurity.

entities.name: ATTACK TECHNIQUE
entities.description: Attack techniques are methods used by adversaries to exploit vulnerabilities in systems, gather information, or gain unauthorized access.

entities.name: SOFTWARE
entities.description: Software refers to the programs and operating information used by a computer, which adversaries may target to gather information about a victim's host software.

entities.name: CLIENT CONFIGURATIONS
entities.description: Client configurations refer to the settings and details of a user's client system, which adversaries may gather to aid in targeting.

entities.name: ACTIVE SCANNING
entities.description: Active scanning is a technique used by adversaries to gather information about a system by probing it for responses, such as listening ports and server banners.

entities.name: PHISHING FOR INFORMATION
entities.description: Phishing for information is a method used by adversaries to trick individuals into revealing sensitive information, often through deceptive emails or websites.

entities.name: RECONNAISSANCE
entities.description: Reconnaissance is the phase in which adversaries gather information about a target to identify vulnerabilities and plan their attack.

entities.name: INITIAL ACCESS
entities.description: Initial access refers to the methods used by adversaries to gain entry into a target system or network.

chunk:
There are 6 software using the attack technique called Bootkit. Their names are as follows:
* Carberp
* WhisperGate
* TrickBot
* ROCKBOOT
* BOOTRASH
* FinFisher

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Carberp
Software description: [Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) is a credential and information stealing malware that has been active since at least 2009. [Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484)'s source code was leaked online in 2013, and subsequently used as the foundation for the [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) backdoor.(Citation: Trend Micro Carberp February 2014)(Citation: KasperskyCarbanak)(Citation: RSA Carbanak November 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: WhisperGate
Software description: [WhisperGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0689) is a multi-stage wiper designed to look like ransomware that has been used against multiple government, non-profit, and information technology organizations in Ukraine since at least January 2022.(Citation: Cybereason WhisperGate February 2022)(Citation: Unit 42 WhisperGate January 2022)(Citation: Microsoft WhisperGate January 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TrickBot
Software description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) is a Trojan spyware program written in C++ that first emerged in September 2016 as a possible successor to [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024). [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) was developed and initially used by [Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) for targeting banking sites in North America, Australia, and throughout Europe; it has since been used against all sectors worldwide as part of "big game hunting" ransomware campaigns.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Fidelis TrickBot Oct 2016)(Citation: IBM TrickBot Nov 2016)(Citation: CrowdStrike Wizard Spider October 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ROCKBOOT
Software description: [ROCKBOOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0112) is a [Bootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1542/003) that has been used by an unidentified, suspected China-based group. (Citation: FireEye Bootkits)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BOOTRASH
Software description: [BOOTRASH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0114) is a [Bootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1542/003) that targets Windows operating systems. It has been used by threat actors that target the financial sector.(Citation: Mandiant M Trends 2016)(Citation: FireEye Bootkits)(Citation: FireEye BOOTRASH SANS)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FinFisher
Software description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) is a government-grade commercial surveillance spyware reportedly sold exclusively to government agencies for use in targeted and lawful criminal investigations. It is heavily obfuscated and uses multiple anti-analysis techniques. It has other variants including [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176). (Citation: FinFisher Citation) (Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21) (Citation: FireEye FinSpy Sept 2017) (Citation: Securelist BlackOasis Oct 2017) (Citation: Microsoft FinFisher March 2018)
Platforms: Windows, Android

entities.name: CARBERP
entities.description: Carberp is a credential and information stealing malware that has been active since at least 2009, with its source code leaked online in 2013 and used as the foundation for the Carbanak backdoor.

entities.name: WHISPERGATE
entities.description: WhisperGate is a multi-stage wiper designed to look like ransomware, used against multiple organizations in Ukraine since at least January 2022.

entities.name: TRICKBOT
entities.description: TrickBot is a Trojan spyware program that first emerged in September 2016, initially used by Wizard Spider for targeting banking sites and later used in ransomware campaigns worldwide.

entities.name: ROCKBOOT
entities.description: ROCKBOOT is a Bootkit used by an unidentified, suspected China-based group.

entities.name: BOOTRASH
entities.description: BOOTRASH is a Bootkit targeting Windows operating systems, used by threat actors in the financial sector.

entities.name: FINFISHER
entities.description: FinFisher is a government-grade commercial surveillance spyware sold exclusively to government agencies for targeted investigations, heavily obfuscated with anti-analysis techniques.

entities.name: WIZARD SPIDER
entities.description: Wizard Spider is a cybercriminal group known for developing and deploying the TrickBot malware and engaging in various ransomware campaigns.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform on which various malware, including Carberp, WhisperGate, TrickBot, ROCKBOOT, BOOTRASH, and FinFisher, operate.

entities.name: ANDROID
entities.description: Android is a mobile operating system platform on which FinFisher operates, in addition to Windows.

There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Launch Daemon. Their names are as follows:
* User Account Management 
* Audit 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that involves managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts to enhance security.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a mitigation method that involves performing audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, and configurations to identify potential weaknesses.

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Systemd Service. Their names are as follows:
* User Account Management 
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 
* Privileged Account Management 
* Limit Software Installation 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Limit Software Installation
Mitigation method description: Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that involves managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts to enhance security against attacks.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that involves setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts to limit access and enhance security.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that focuses on managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root, to prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: LIMIT SOFTWARE INSTALLATION
entities.description: Limit Software Installation is a mitigation method that blocks users or groups from installing unapproved software to reduce the risk of security breaches.

chunk: There are 10 software using the attack technique called Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification. Their names are as follows: * OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D * P.A.S. Webshell * Kinsing * OSX/Shlayer * COATHANGER * Black Basta * Dok * XCSSET * Penquin * Bundlore The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows: Software name: *** Software description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates. Software name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D Software description: [OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) is a macOS backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050). First discovered in 2015, [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has continued to make improvements using a plugin architecture to extend capabilities, specifically using `.dylib` files. [OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) can also determine it's permission level and execute according to access type (`root` or `user`).(Citation: Unit42 OceanLotus 2017)(Citation: TrendMicro MacOS April 2018)(Citation: Trend Micro MacOS Backdoor November 2020) Platforms: macOS Software name: P.A.S. Webshell Software description: [P.A.S. Webshell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0598) is a publicly available multifunctional PHP webshell in use since at least 2016 that provides remote access and execution on target web servers.(Citation: ANSSI Sandworm January 2021) Platforms: Linux, Windows Software name: Kinsing Software description: [Kinsing](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0599) is Golang-based malware that runs a cryptocurrency miner and attempts to spread itself to other hosts in the victim environment. (Citation: Aqua Kinsing April 2020)(Citation: Sysdig Kinsing November 2020)(Citation: Aqua Security Cloud Native Threat Report June 2021) Platforms: Containers, Linux Software name: OSX/Shlayer Software description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) is a Trojan designed to install adware on macOS that was first discovered in 2018.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)(Citation: Intego Shlayer Feb 2018) Platforms: macOS Software name: COATHANGER Software description: [COATHANGER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1105) is a remote access tool (RAT) targeting FortiGate networking appliances. First used in 2023 in targeted intrusions against military and government entities in the Netherlands along with other victims, [COATHANGER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1105) was disclosed in early 2024, with a high confidence assessment linking this malware to a state-sponsored entity in the People's Republic of China. [COATHANGER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1105) is delivered after gaining access to a FortiGate device, with in-the-wild observations linked to exploitation of CVE-2022-42475. The name [COATHANGER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1105) is based on a unique string in the malware used to encrypt configuration files on disk: “She took his coat and hung it up”.(Citation: NCSC-NL COATHANGER Feb 2024) Platforms: Linux, Network Software name: Black Basta Software description: [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) is ransomware written in C++ that has been offered within the ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) model since at least April 2022; there are variants that target Windows and VMWare ESXi servers. [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) operations have included the double extortion technique where in addition to demanding ransom for decrypting the files of targeted organizations the cyber actors also threaten to post sensitive information to a leak site if the ransom is not paid. [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) affiliates have targeted multiple high-value organizations, with the largest number of victims based in the U.S. Based on similarities in TTPs, leak sites, payment sites, and negotiation tactics, security researchers assess the [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) RaaS operators could include current or former members of the [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) group.(Citation: Palo Alto Networks Black Basta August 2022)(Citation: Deep Instinct Black Basta August 2022)(Citation: Minerva Labs Black Basta May 2022)(Citation: Avertium Black Basta June 2022)(Citation: NCC Group Black Basta June 2022)(Citation: Cyble Black Basta May 2022) Platforms: Windows Software name: Dok Software description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) is a Trojan application disguised as a .zip file that is able to collect user credentials and install a malicious proxy server to redirect a user's network traffic (i.e. [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557)).(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)(Citation: hex

)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Dok
Software description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) is a Trojan application disguised as a .zip file that is able to collect user credentials and install a malicious proxy server to redirect a user's network traffic (i.e. [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557)).(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)(Citation: hexed osx.dok analysis 2019)(Citation: CheckPoint Dok)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: XCSSET
Software description: [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) is a macOS modular backdoor that targets Xcode application developers. [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) was first observed in August 2020 and has been used to install a backdoor component, modify browser applications, conduct collection, and provide ransomware-like encryption capabilities.(Citation: trendmicro xcsset xcode project 2020)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: Penquin
Software description: [Penquin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0587) is a remote access trojan (RAT) with multiple versions used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) to target Linux systems since at least 2014.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Penquin December 2014)(Citation: Leonardo Turla Penquin May 2020)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: Bundlore
Software description: [Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482) is adware written for macOS that has been in use since at least 2015. Though categorized as adware, [Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482) has many features associated with more traditional backdoors.(Citation: MacKeeper Bundlore Apr 2019)
Platforms: macOS

There are 1 software using the attack technique called Domains. Their names are as follows:
* DarkGate

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: DarkGate
Software description: [DarkGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1111) first emerged in 2018 and has evolved into an initial access and data gathering tool associated with various criminal cyber operations. Written in Delphi and named "DarkGate" by its author, [DarkGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1111) is associated with credential theft, cryptomining, cryptotheft, and pre-ransomware actions.(Citation: Ensilo Darkgate 2018) DarkGate use increased significantly starting in 2022 and is under active development by its author, who provides it as a Malware-as-a-Service offering.(Citation: Trellix Darkgate 2023)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: DARKGATE
entities.description: DarkGate is a software tool that first emerged in 2018, associated with initial access and data gathering in various criminal cyber operations, including credential theft and cryptomining, and is provided as a Malware-as-a-Service offering.

entities.name: CREDENTIAL THEFT
entities.description: Credential theft is a type of cybercrime where an attacker steals user credentials, often associated with the use of DarkGate.

entities.name: CRYPTOMINING
entities.description: Cryptomining is the process of validating transactions on a blockchain and earning cryptocurrency, which is one of the activities associated with DarkGate.

entities.name: CRYPTOTHEFT
entities.description: Cryptotheft refers to the act of stealing cryptocurrency, which is another activity linked to DarkGate.

entities.name: PRE-RANSOMWARE ACTIONS
entities.description: Pre-ransomware actions are steps taken by attackers before deploying ransomware, which are associated with the functionalities of DarkGate.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform on which DarkGate operates.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called DCSync. Their names are as follows:
* Password Policies 
* Active Directory Configuration 
* Privileged Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Password Policies
Mitigation method description: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

Mitigation method name: Active Directory Configuration
Mitigation method description: Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: PASSWORD POLICIES
entities.description: Password Policies are a mitigation method that involves setting and enforcing secure password policies for accounts to enhance security against attacks like DCSync.

entities.name: ACTIVE DIRECTORY CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Active Directory Configuration is a mitigation method that involves configuring Active Directory to prevent the use of certain techniques, such as using SID Filtering.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that focuses on managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

Mitigation method name: Code Signing
Mitigation method description: Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

Software name: SUNSPOT
Software description: [SUNSPOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0562) is an implant that injected the [SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) backdoor into the SolarWinds Orion software update framework. It was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least February 2020.(Citation: CrowdStrike SUNSPOT Implant January 2021) 
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 4 software using the attack technique called NTDS. Their names are as follows:
* CrackMapExec
* esentutl
* Impacket
* Koadic

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: CrackMapExec
Software description: [CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488), or CME, is a post-exploitation tool developed in Python and designed for penetration testing against networks. [CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488) collects Active Directory information to conduct lateral movement through targeted networks.(Citation: CME Github September 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: esentutl
Software description: [esentutl](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0404) is a command-line tool that provides database utilities for the Windows Extensible Storage Engine.(Citation: Microsoft Esentutl)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Impacket
Software description: [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) is an open source collection of modules written in Python for programmatically constructing and manipulating network protocols. [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) contains several tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.(Citation: Impacket Tools)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: Koadic
Software description: [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool that is publicly available on GitHub. [Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) has several options for staging payloads and creating implants, and performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host.(Citation: Github Koadic)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: MalwareBytes LazyScripter Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: CRACKMAPEXEC
entities.description: CrackMapExec, or CME, is a post-exploitation tool developed in Python designed for penetration testing against networks, collecting Active Directory information for lateral movement through targeted networks.

entities.name: ESENTUTL
entities.description: esentutl is a command-line tool that provides database utilities for the Windows Extensible Storage Engine.

entities.name: IMPACKET
entities.description: Impacket is an open source collection of modules written in Python for constructing and manipulating network protocols, containing tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.

entities.name: KOADIC
entities.description: Koadic is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool available on GitHub, offering options for staging payloads and creating implants, primarily using Windows Script Host.
