key="d1">CrackMapExec, or CME, is a post-exploitation tool developed in Python designed for penetration testing against networks, collecting Active Directory information for lateral movement through targeted networks.</data>      <data key="d2">33094661c9918c407146d17011e60d94</data>    </node>    <node id="ESENTUTL">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">esentutl is a command-line tool that provides database utilities for the Windows Extensible Storage Engine.</data>      <data key="d2">33094661c9918c407146d17011e60d94</data>    </node>    <node id="IMPACKET">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Impacket is an open source collection of modules written in Python for constructing and manipulating network protocols, containing tools for remote service execution, Kerberos manipulation, Windows credential dumping, packet sniffing, and relay attacks.</data>      <data key="d2">33094661c9918c407146d17011e60d94</data>    </node>    <node id="KOADIC">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Koadic is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool available on GitHub, offering options for staging payloads and creating implants, primarily using Windows Script Host.</data>      <data key="d2">33094661c9918c407146d17011e60d94</data>    </node>    <node id="NTDS">      <data key="d0" />      <data </edge>    <edge source="CRACKMAPEXEC" target="KOADIC">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">CrackMapExec and Koadic are both post-exploitation tools used in penetration testing, key="d3">5.0</data>      <data key="d4">CrackMapExec and esentutl are both tools that can be used in the context of Windows environments, although they serve different purposes.</data>      <data key="d5">33094661c9918c407146d17011e60d94</data>    </edge>    <edge source="CRACKMAPEXEC" target="NTDS">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">CrackMapExec is a tool that can be used to exploit the NTDS attack technique during penetration testing.</data>      <data key="d5">33094661c9918c407146d17011e60d94</data>    </edge>    <edge source="ESENTUTL" target="IMPACKET">      <data target="NTDS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">esentutl may be indirectly related to NTDS as it provides database utilities that could be relevant in certain exploitation    <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">Koadic can be employed to exploit the NTDS attack technique, particularly in Windows environments.</data>      <data There are 5 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Cached Domain Credentials. Their names are as follows:
* Active Directory Configuration 
* User Training 
* Password Policies 
* Operating System Configuration 
* Privileged Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Active Directory Configuration
Mitigation method description: Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

Mitigation method name: Password Policies
Mitigation method description: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: ACTIVE DIRECTORY CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Active Directory Configuration is a mitigation method that involves configuring Active Directory to prevent the use of certain techniques, such as using SID Filtering.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method aimed at training users to recognize access or manipulation attempts by adversaries to reduce risks associated with spearphishing and social engineering.

entities.name: PASSWORD POLICIES
entities.description: Password Policies are a set of rules that enforce secure password practices for accounts to enhance security.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration involves making changes to the operating system settings to harden the system against various attack techniques.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a method that focuses on managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions of privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: CACHED DOMAIN CREDENTIALS
entities.description: Cached Domain Credentials is an attack technique that involves the exploitation of stored credentials to gain unauthorized access to systems.

* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that involves setting directory and file permissions to limit access, ensuring that permissions are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

chunk:
There are 7 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called LSASS Memory. Their names are as follows:
* Operating System Configuration 
* Credential Access Protection 
* Privileged Process Integrity 
* Privileged Account Management 
* User Training 
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 
* Password Policies 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Mitigation method name: Credential Access Protection
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Process Integrity
Mitigation method description: Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: Password Policies
Mitigation method description: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method that involves making configuration changes to harden the operating system against attack techniques.

entities.name: CREDENTIAL ACCESS PROTECTION
entities.description: Credential Access Protection is a mitigation method aimed at preventing successful credential access by adversaries, including blocking credential dumping.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED PROCESS INTEGRITY
entities.description: Privileged Process Integrity is a mitigation method that protects high-privilege processes from being manipulated by adversaries through various integrity enforcement measures.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that involves managing the creation, modification, and permissions of privileged accounts to enhance security.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method that educates users about potential access or manipulation attempts by adversaries to reduce risks associated with social engineering.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that aims to prevent suspicious behavior patterns on endpoint systems to enhance security.

entities.name: PASSWORD POLICIES
entities.description: Password Policies is a mitigation method that sets and enforces secure password practices for user accounts.

entities.name: LSASS MEMORY
entities.description: LSASS Memory is an attack technique that targets the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service to extract sensitive information from memory.

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Security Account Manager. Their names are as follows:
* Password Policies 
* Privileged Account Management 
* Operating System Configuration 
* User Training 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Password Policies
Mitigation method description: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

entities.name: PASSWORD POLICIES
entities.description: Password Policies are a mitigation method that involves setting and enforcing secure password policies for accounts to enhance security against attacks.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method that involves making configuration changes related to the operating system to harden the system against attack techniques.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method that educates users about access or manipulation attempts by adversaries to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing and social engineering attacks.

entities.name: SECURITY ACCOUNT MANAGER
entities.description: Security Account Manager is an attack technique that can be mitigated through various methods to enhance security and protect user accounts.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk: There are 5 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Create or Modify System Process. Their names are as follows: * Launch Daemon * Container Service * Launch Agent * Systemd Service * Windows Service The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows: Attack technique name: *** Attack technique description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target. Attack technique name: Create or Modify System Process Attack technique description: Adversaries may create or modify system-level processes to repeatedly execute malicious payloads as part of persistence. When operating systems boot up, they can start processes that perform background system functions. On Windows and Linux, these system processes are referred to as services.(Citation: TechNet Services) On macOS, launchd processes known as [Launch Daemon](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/004) and [Launch Agent](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/001) are run to finish system initialization and load user specific parameters.(Citation: AppleDocs Launch Agent Daemons) Adversaries may install new services, daemons, or agents that can be configured to execute at startup or a repeatable interval in order to establish persistence. Similarly, adversaries may modify existing services, daemons, or agents to achieve the same effect. Services, daemons, or agents may be created with administrator privileges but executed under root/SYSTEM privileges. Adversaries may leverage this functionality to create or modify system processes in order to escalate privileges.(Citation: OSX Malware Detection) Platforms: Windows, macOS, Linux, Containers Attack technique name: Launch Daemon Attack technique description: Adversaries may create or modify Launch Daemons to execute malicious payloads as part of persistence. Launch Daemons are plist files used to interact with Launchd, the service management framework used by macOS. Launch Daemons require elevated privileges to install, are executed for every user on a system prior to login, and run in the background without the need for user interaction. During the macOS initialization startup, the launchd process loads the parameters for launch-on-demand system-level daemons from plist files found in /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/ and /Library/LaunchDaemons/. Required Launch Daemons parameters include a Label to identify the task, Program to provide a path to the executable, and RunAtLoad to specify when the task is run. Launch Daemons are often used to provide access to shared resources, updates to software, or conduct automation tasks.(Citation: AppleDocs Launch Agent Daemons)(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence)(Citation: launchd Keywords for plists) Adversaries may install a Launch Daemon configured to execute at startup by using the RunAtLoad parameter set to true and the Program parameter set to the malicious executable path. The daemon name may be disguised by using a name from a related operating system or benign software (i.e. [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036)). When the Launch Daemon is executed, the program inherits administrative permissions.(Citation: WireLurker)(Citation: OSX Malware Detection) Additionally, system configuration changes (such as the installation of third party package managing software) may cause folders such as usr/local/bin to become globally writeable. So, it is possible for poor configurations to allow an adversary to modify executables referenced by current Launch Daemon's plist files.(Citation: LaunchDaemon Hijacking)(Citation: sentinelone macos persist Jun 2019) Platforms: macOS Attack technique name: Container Service Attack technique description: Adversaries may create or modify container or container cluster management tools that run as daemons, agents, or services on individual hosts. These include software for creating and managing individual containers, such as Docker and Podman, as well as container cluster node-level agents such as kubelet. By modifying these services, an adversary may be able to achieve persistence or escalate their privileges on a host. For example, by using the `docker run` or `podman run` command with the `restart=always` directive, a container can be configured to persistently restart on the host.(Citation: AquaSec TeamTNT 2023) A user with access to the (rootful) docker command may also be able to escalate their privileges on the host.(Citation: GTFOBins Docker) In Kubernetes environments, DaemonSets allow an adversary to persistently [Deploy Container](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1610)s on all nodes, including ones added later to the cluster.(Citation: Aquasec Kubernetes Attack 2023)(Citation: Kubernetes DaemonSet) Pods can also be deployed to specific nodes using the `nodeSelector` or `nodeName` fields in the pod spec.(Citation: Kubernetes Assigning Pods to Nodes)(Citation: AppSecco Kubernetes Namespace Breakout 2020) Note that containers can also be configured to run as [Systemd Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/002)s.(Citation: Podman Systemd)(Citation: Docker Systemd) Platforms: Containers Attack technique name: Launch Agent Attack technique description: Adversaries may create or modify launch agents to repeatedly execute malicious payloads as part of persistence. When a user logs in, a per-user launchd process is started which loads the parameters for each launch-on-demand user agent from the property list (.plist) file found in /System/Library

chunk: .org/techniques/T1543/002)s.(Citation: Podman Systemd)(Citation: Docker Systemd) Platforms: Containers Attack technique name: Launch Agent Attack technique description: Adversaries may create or modify launch agents to repeatedly execute malicious payloads as part of persistence. When a user logs in, a per-user launchd process is started which loads the parameters for each launch-on-demand user agent from the property list (.plist) file found in /System/Library/LaunchAgents, /Library/LaunchAgents, and ~/Library/LaunchAgents.(Citation: AppleDocs Launch Agent Daemons)(Citation: OSX Keydnap malware) (Citation: Antiquated Mac Malware) Property list files use the Label, ProgramArguments , and RunAtLoad keys to identify the Launch Agent's name, executable location, and execution time.(Citation: OSX.Dok Malware) Launch Agents are often installed to perform updates to programs, launch user specified programs at login, or to conduct other developer tasks. Launch Agents can also be executed using the [Launchctl](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1569/001) command. Adversaries may install a new Launch Agent that executes at login by placing a .plist file into the appropriate folders with the RunAtLoad or KeepAlive keys set to true.(Citation: Sofacy Komplex Trojan)(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence) The Launch Agent name may be disguised by using a name from the related operating system or benign software. Launch Agents are created with user level privileges and execute with user level permissions.(Citation: OSX Malware Detection)(Citation: OceanLotus for OS X) Platforms: macOS Attack technique name: Systemd Service Attack technique description: Adversaries may create or modify systemd services to repeatedly execute malicious payloads as part of persistence. Systemd is a system and service manager commonly used for managing background daemon processes (also known as services) and other system resources.(Citation: Linux man-pages: systemd January 2014) Systemd is the default initialization (init) system on many Linux distributions replacing legacy init systems, including SysVinit and Upstart, while remaining backwards compatible. Systemd utilizes unit configuration files with the `.service` file extension to encode information about a service's process. By default, system level unit files are stored in the `/systemd/system` directory of the root owned directories (`/`). User level unit files are stored in the `/systemd/user` directories of the user owned directories (`$HOME`).(Citation: lambert systemd 2022) Inside the `.service` unit files, the following directives are used to execute commands:(Citation: freedesktop systemd.service) * `ExecStart`, `ExecStartPre`, and `ExecStartPost` directives execute when a service is started manually by `systemctl` or on system start if the service is set to automatically start. * `ExecReload` directive executes when a service restarts. * `ExecStop`, `ExecStopPre`, and `ExecStopPost` directives execute when a service is stopped. Adversaries have created new service files, altered the commands a `.service` file’s directive executes, and modified the user directive a `.service` file executes as, which could result in privilege escalation. Adversaries may also place symbolic links in these directories, enabling systemd to find these payloads regardless of where they reside on the filesystem.(Citation: Anomali Rocke March 2019)(Citation: airwalk backdoor unix systems)(Citation: Rapid7 Service Persistence 22JUNE2016) The .service file’s User directive can be used to run service as a specific user, which could result in privilege escalation based on specific user/group permissions. Platforms: Linux Attack technique name: Windows Service Attack technique description: Adversaries may create or modify Windows services to repeatedly execute malicious payloads as part of persistence. When Windows boots up, it starts programs or applications called services that perform background system functions.(Citation: TechNet Services) Windows service configuration information, including the file path to the service's executable or recovery programs/commands, is stored in the Windows Registry. Adversaries may install a new service or modify an existing service to execute at startup in order to persist on a system. Service configurations can be set or modified using system utilities (such as sc.exe), by directly modifying the Registry, or by interacting directly with the Windows API. Adversaries may also use services to install and execute malicious drivers. For example, after dropping a driver file (ex: `.sys`) to disk, the payload can be loaded and registered via [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) functions such as `CreateServiceW()` (or manually via functions such as `ZwLoadDriver()` and `ZwSetValueKey()`), by creating the required service Registry values (i.e. [Modify Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1112)), or by using command-line utilities such as `PnPUtil.exe`.(Citation: Symantec W.32 Stuxnet Dossier)(Citation: Crowdstrike DriveSlayer February 2022)(Citation: Unit42 AcidBox June 2020) Adversaries may leverage these drivers as [Rootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1014)s to hide the presence of malicious activity on a system. Adversaries may also load a signed yet vulnerable driver onto a compromised machine (known as "Bring Your Own Vulner

entities.name: LAUNCH AGENT
entities.description: Launch Agents are processes that execute at user login to perform tasks such as updates or launching programs, often used by adversaries for persistence in macOS systems.

entities.name: SYSTEMD SERVICE
entities.description: Systemd Services are background processes managed by the systemd system and service manager, commonly used in Linux for executing commands and managing system resources.

entities.name: WINDOWS SERVICE
entities.description: Windows Services are background applications that start when Windows boots, performing essential system functions and can be manipulated by adversaries for persistence.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system developed by Apple Inc. for Macintosh computers, known for its user-friendly interface and security features.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system kernel that is widely used in various distributions, known for its flexibility and robustness in server environments.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is a series of operating systems developed by Microsoft, widely used for personal computers and known for its graphical user interface.

entities.name: PROPERTY LIST FILE
entities.description: Property list files are used in macOS to store configuration settings for Launch Agents, detailing how and when they should execute.

entities.name: EXECSTART
entities.description: ExecStart is a directive in systemd service files that specifies the command to execute when starting a service.

entities.name: EXECSTOP
entities.description: ExecStop is a directive in systemd service files that specifies the command to execute when stopping a service.

entities.name: EXECRELOAD
entities.description: ExecReload is a directive in systemd service files that specifies the command to execute when a service is reloaded.

entities.name: WINDOWS REGISTRY
entities.description: The Windows Registry is a database that stores configuration settings and options for the operating system and installed applications, including service configurations.

chunk:
Citation: Symantec W.32 Stuxnet Dossier)(Citation: Crowdstrike DriveSlayer February 2022)(Citation: Unit42 AcidBox June 2020) Adversaries may leverage these drivers as [Rootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1014)s to hide the presence of malicious activity on a system. Adversaries may also load a signed yet vulnerable driver onto a compromised machine (known as "Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver" (BYOVD)) as part of [Exploitation for Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1068).(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2020)(Citation: Unit42 AcidBox June 2020)

Services may be created with administrator privileges but are executed under SYSTEM privileges, so an adversary may also use a service to escalate privileges. Adversaries may also directly start services through [Service Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1569/002).

To make detection analysis more challenging, malicious services may also incorporate [Masquerade Task or Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036/004) (ex: using a service and/or payload name related to a legitimate OS or benign software component). Adversaries may also create ‘hidden’ services (i.e., [Hide Artifacts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564)), for example by using the `sc sdset` command to set service permissions via the Service Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL). This may hide a Windows service from the view of standard service enumeration methods such as `Get-Service`, `sc query`, and `services.exe`.(Citation: SANS 1)(Citation: SANS 2)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: SYMANTEC
entities.description: Symantec is a cybersecurity company known for its antivirus software and threat intelligence services, including the analysis of malware like Stuxnet.

entities.name: CROWDSTRIKE
entities.description: Crowdstrike is a cybersecurity technology company that provides endpoint protection and threat intelligence, including the DriveSlayer report.

entities.name: UNIT42
entities.description: Unit42 is a threat intelligence team at Palo Alto Networks that analyzes malware and cyber threats, including AcidBox.

entities.name: ESET
entities.description: ESET is a global cybersecurity company that provides antivirus and internet security software, including the InvisiMole report.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system developed by Microsoft, widely used in personal computers and enterprise environments.

entities.name: ACIDBOX
entities.description: AcidBox is a malware analysis event reported by Unit42, detailing specific cyber threats and vulnerabilities.

entities.name: STUXNET
entities.description: Stuxnet is a computer worm that was discovered in 2010, designed to target and disrupt industrial control systems.

entities.name: INVISIMOLE
entities.description: InvisiMole is a malware variant reported by ESET, known for its stealthy operations and advanced capabilities.

entities.name: BYOVD
entities.description: Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver (BYOVD) is a technique where adversaries load a signed yet vulnerable driver onto a compromised machine to exploit it.

entities.name: EXPLOITATION FOR PRIVILEGE ESCALATION
entities.description: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation is a technique used by adversaries to gain higher access rights on a system.

entities.name: SERVICE EXECUTION
entities.description: Service Execution is a method by which adversaries can start services to escalate privileges on a compromised system.

entities.name: HIDE ARTIFACTS
entities.description: Hide Artifacts is a technique used by adversaries to conceal their presence and activities on a system.

entities.name: MASQUERADE TASK OR SERVICE
entities.description: Masquerade Task or Service is a technique where adversaries use names related to legitimate software to disguise malicious services.

entities.name: SERVICE DESCRIPTOR DEFINITION LANGUAGE
entities.description: Service Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) is used to set service permissions, which can help hide services from standard enumeration methods.

There are 1 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Domain Account. Their names are as follows:
* Operating System Configuration 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method that involves making configuration changes to the operating system to enhance security and harden the system against attack techniques.

chunk:
There are 8 software using the attack technique called Steal Web Session Cookie. Their names are as follows:
* Grandoreiro
* CookieMiner
* QakBot
* EVILNUM
* Chaes
* BLUELIGHT
* XCSSET
* TajMahal

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Grandoreiro
Software description: [Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) is a banking trojan written in Delphi that was first observed in 2016 and uses a Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) business model. [Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) has confirmed victims in Brazil, Mexico, Portugal, and Spain.(Citation: Securelist Brazilian Banking Malware July 2020)(Citation: ESET Grandoreiro April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CookieMiner
Software description: [CookieMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0492) is mac-based malware that targets information associated with cryptocurrency exchanges as well as enabling cryptocurrency mining on the victim system itself. It was first discovered in the wild in 2019.(Citation: Unit42 CookieMiner Jan 2019)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EVILNUM
Software description: [EVILNUM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0568) is fully capable backdoor that was first identified in 2018. [EVILNUM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0568) is used by the APT group [Evilnum](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0120) which has the same name.(Citation: ESET EvilNum July 2020)(Citation: Prevailion EvilNum May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Chaes
Software description: [Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) is a multistage information stealer written in several programming languages that collects login credentials, credit card numbers, and other financial information. [Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) was first observed in 2020, and appears to primarily target victims in Brazil as well as other e-commerce customers in Latin America.(Citation: Cybereason Chaes Nov 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BLUELIGHT
Software description: [BLUELIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0657) is a remote access Trojan used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) that was first observed in early 2021.(Citation: Volexity InkySquid BLUELIGHT August 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: XCSSET
Software description: [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) is a macOS modular backdoor that targets Xcode application developers. [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) was first observed in August 2020 and has been used to install a backdoor component, modify browser applications, conduct collection, and provide ransomware-like encryption capabilities.(Citation: trendmicro xcsset xcode project 2020)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: TajMahal
Software description: [TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) is a multifunctional spying framework that has been in use since at least 2014. [TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) is comprised of two separate packages, named Tokyo and Yokohama, and can deploy up to 80 plugins.(Citation: Kaspersky TajMahal April 2019)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 4 software using the attack technique called RC Scripts. Their names are as follows:
* HiddenWasp
* Green Lambert
* Cyclops Blink
* iKitten

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: HiddenWasp
Software description: [HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) is a Linux-based Trojan used to target systems for remote control. It comes in the form of a statically linked ELF binary with stdlibc++.(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: Green Lambert
Software description: [Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) is a modular backdoor that security researchers assess has been used by an advanced threat group referred to as Longhorn and The Lamberts. First reported in 2017, the Windows variant of [Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) may have been used as early as 2008; a macOS version was uploaded to a multiscanner service in September 2014.(Citation: Kaspersky Lamberts Toolkit April 2017)(Citation: Objective See Green Lambert for OSX Oct 2021)  
Platforms: Windows, iOS, macOS, Linux

Software name: Cyclops Blink
Software description: [Cyclops Blink](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0687) is a modular malware that has been used in widespread campaigns by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) since at least 2019 to target Small/Home Office (SOHO) network devices, including WatchGuard and Asus.(Citation: NCSC Cyclops Blink February 2022)(Citation: NCSC CISA Cyclops Blink Advisory February 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Cyclops Blink March 2022)
Platforms: Network

Software name: iKitten
Software description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) is a macOS exfiltration agent  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

entities.name: HIDDENWASP
entities.description: HiddenWasp is a Linux-based Trojan used to target systems for remote control, coming in the form of a statically linked ELF binary with stdlibc++.

entities.name: GREEN LAMBERT
entities.description: Green Lambert is a modular backdoor associated with an advanced threat group known as Longhorn and The Lamberts, with variants for Windows, iOS, macOS, and Linux.

entities.name: CYCLOPS BLINK
entities.description: Cyclops Blink is a modular malware used in campaigns by Sandworm Team to target Small/Home Office network devices.

entities.name: IKITTEN
entities.description: iKitten is a macOS exfiltration agent used for data extraction.

entities.name: LONGHORN
entities.description: Longhorn is an advanced threat group associated with the use of Green Lambert malware.

entities.name: MITRE
entities.description: MITRE is a not-for-profit organization that operates Federally Funded Research and Development Centers (FFRDCs) and provides technical expertise in cybersecurity, including the documentation of various malware types.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform on which Green Lambert operates.

entities.name: IOS
entities.description: iOS is an operating system platform on which Green Lambert operates.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform on which both Green Lambert and iKitten operate.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform on which HiddenWasp and Green Lambert operate.

entities.name: NETWORK
entities.description: Network refers to the platform targeted by Cyclops Blink malware.)<|COMPLETE|>

Software description: ***
Platforms: ***

Software name: Mimikatz
Software description: [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) is a credential dumper capable of obtaining plaintext Windows account logins and passwords, along with many other features that make it useful for testing the security of networks. (Citation: Deply Mimikatz) (Citation: Adsecurity Mimikatz Guide)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: MIMIKATZ
entities.description: Mimikatz is a credential dumper software capable of obtaining plaintext Windows account logins and passwords, useful for testing the security of networks.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform on which Mimikatz operates and is commonly used in enterprise environments.)<|COMPLETE|>

Software name: Epic
Software description: [Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) is a backdoor that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). (Citation: Kaspersky Turla)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Power Loader
Software description: [Power Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0177) is modular code sold in the cybercrime market used as a downloader in malware families such as Carberp, Redyms and Gapz. (Citation: MalwareTech Power Loader Aug 2013) (Citation: WeLiveSecurity Gapz and Redyms Mar 2013)
Platforms: None

There are 1 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Serverless. Their names are as follows:
* Pre-compromise 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Pre-compromise
Mitigation method description: This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

entities.name: SERVERLESS
entities.description: Serverless is an attack technique that requires specific mitigation methods to prevent initial access by adversaries.

entities.name: PRE-COMPROMISE
entities.description: Pre-compromise refers to mitigation activities that are applicable before an adversary gains initial access, focusing on reconnaissance and resource development techniques.

entities.name: INITIAL ACCESS
entities.description: Initial access refers to the stage in a cyber attack where an adversary gains entry into a system or network.

entities.name: RECONNAISSANCE
entities.description: Reconnaissance is a phase in cyber attacks where adversaries gather information about a target to identify vulnerabilities.

entities.name: RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT
entities.description: Resource development involves the preparation and acquisition of tools and resources necessary for executing a cyber attack.

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Screen Capture. Their names are as follows:
* Pupy
* PcShare
* Empire
* SILENTTRINITY
* Brute Ratel C4
* PowerSploit
* Sliver
* Remcos
* ConnectWise
* RemoteUtilities

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: PcShare
Software description: [PcShare](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1050) is an open source remote access tool that has been modified and used by Chinese threat actors, most notably during the FunnyDream campaign since late 2018.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)(Citation: GitHub PcShare 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Brute Ratel C4
Software description: [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) is a commercial red-teaming and adversarial attack simulation tool that first appeared in December 2020. [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was specifically designed to avoid detection by endpoint detection and response (EDR) and antivirus (AV) capabilities, and deploys agents called badgers to enable arbitrary command execution for lateral movement, privilege escalation, and persistence. In September 2022, a cracked version of [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was leaked in the cybercriminal underground, leading to its use by threat actors.(Citation: Dark Vortex Brute Ratel C4)(Citation: Palo Alto Brute Ratel July 2022)(Citation: MDSec Brute Ratel August 2022)(Citation: SANS Brute Ratel October 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Black Basta October 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Sliver
Software description: [Sliver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0633) is an open source, cross-platform, red team command and control framework written in Golang.(Citation: Bishop Fox Sliver Framework August 2019)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Remcos
Software description: [Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) is a closed-source tool that is marketed as a remote control and surveillance software by a company called Breaking Security. [Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) has been observed being used in malware campaigns.(Citation: Riskiq Remcos Jan 2018)(Citation: Talos Remcos Aug 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ConnectWise
Software description: [ConnectWise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0591) is a legitimate remote administration tool

Software name: ConnectWise
Software description: [ConnectWise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0591) is a legitimate remote administration tool that has been used since at least 2016 by threat actors including [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) and [GOLD SOUTHFIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0115) to connect to and conduct lateral movement in target environments.(Citation: Anomali Static Kitten February 2021)(Citation: Trend Micro Muddy Water March 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RemoteUtilities
Software description: [RemoteUtilities](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0592) is a legitimate remote administration tool that has been used by [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) since at least 2021 for execution on target machines.(Citation: Trend Micro Muddy Water March 2021)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Steal Web Session Cookie. Their names are as follows:
* Software Configuration 
* Multi-factor Authentication 
* User Training 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Software Configuration
Mitigation method description: Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

Mitigation method name: Multi-factor Authentication
Mitigation method description: Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

entities.name: SOFTWARE CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Software Configuration involves implementing configuration changes to software to mitigate security risks associated with its operation.

entities.name: MULTI-FACTOR AUTHENTICATION
entities.description: Multi-factor Authentication is a security method that requires two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate a user to a system.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training involves educating users about security risks and how to recognize manipulation attempts to reduce the risk of successful attacks.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation Methods refer to strategies implemented to reduce the risk of security attacks, including various techniques like Software Configuration, Multi-factor Authentication, and User Training.

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called NTDS. Their names are as follows:
* Password Policies 
* Privileged Account Management 
* User Training 
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Password Policies
Mitigation method description: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

entities.name: PASSWORD POLICIES
entities.description: Password Policies are a set of rules designed to enhance security by enforcing secure password practices for accounts.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management involves overseeing the creation, modification, use, and permissions of privileged accounts, such as SYSTEM and root accounts.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a method aimed at educating users about potential security threats, such as spearphishing and social engineering, to reduce risks.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description: Encrypt Sensitive Information refers to the practice of using strong encryption techniques to protect sensitive data from unauthorized access.

entities.description: NTDS is an attack technique that requires specific mitigation methods to prevent or reduce its impact on systems.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk: There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called System Owner/User Discovery. Their names are as follows: The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows: Attack technique name: *** Attack technique description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target. Attack technique name: System Owner/User Discovery Attack technique description: Adversaries may attempt to identify the primary user, currently logged in user, set of users that commonly uses a system, or whether a user is actively using the system. They may do this, for example, by retrieving account usernames or by using [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003). The information may be collected in a number of different ways using other Discovery techniques, because user and username details are prevalent throughout a system and include running process ownership, file/directory ownership, session information, and system logs. Adversaries may use the information from [System Owner/User Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1033) during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. Various utilities and commands may acquire this information, including whoami. In macOS and Linux, the currently logged in user can be identified with w and who. On macOS the dscl . list /Users | grep -v '_' command can also be used to enumerate user accounts. Environment variables, such as %USERNAME% and $USER, may also be used to access this information. On network devices, [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) commands such as `show users` and `show ssh` can be used to display users currently logged into the device.(Citation: show_ssh_users_cmd_cisco)(Citation: US-CERT TA18-106A Network Infrastructure Devices 2018) Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows, Network

entities.name: SYSTEM OWNER/USER DISCOVERY
entities.description: System Owner/User Discovery is an attack technique where adversaries identify the primary user or currently logged-in user of a system, often using various utilities and commands to gather this information.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform that can be targeted by the System Owner/User Discovery technique.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that can be targeted by the System Owner/User Discovery technique.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that can be targeted by the System Owner/User Discovery technique.

entities.name: NETWORK
entities.description: Network devices are platforms that can be targeted by the System Owner/User Discovery technique.

entities.name: OS CREDENTIAL DUMPING
entities.description: OS Credential Dumping is a technique used by adversaries to retrieve account usernames and other sensitive information from operating systems.

entities.name: WHOAMI
entities.description: Whoami is a command-line utility that can be used to identify the currently logged-in user on a system.

entities.name: W
entities.description: The 'w' command is a utility in macOS and Linux that displays who is logged on and what they are doing.

entities.name: WHO
entities.description: The 'who' command is a utility in macOS and Linux that shows who is logged on to the system.

entities.name: DSCL
entities.description: DSCL (Directory Service command line utility) is a command used in macOS to list user accounts on the system.

entities.name: ENVIRONMENT VARIABLES
entities.description: Environment variables like %USERNAME% and $USER are used to access user information in various operating systems.

entities.name: NETWORK DEVICE CLI
entities.description: Network Device CLI commands are used to interact with network devices and can display users currently logged into the device.

entities.name: SHOW USERS
entities.description: The 'show users' command is a Network Device CLI command that displays users currently logged into a network device.

entities.name: SHOW SSH
entities.description: The 'show ssh' command is a Network Device CLI command that displays SSH session information, including users logged in via SSH.

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Password Guessing. Their names are as follows:
* Update Software 
* Multi-factor Authentication 
* Password Policies 
* Account Use Policies 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Update Software
Mitigation method description: Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

Mitigation method name: Multi-factor Authentication
Mitigation method description: Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.

Mitigation method name: Password Policies
Mitigation method description: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

Mitigation method name: Account Use Policies
Mitigation method description: Configure features related to account use like login attempt lockouts, specific login times, etc.

entities.name: UPDATE SOFTWARE
entities.description: Update Software is a mitigation method that involves performing regular software updates to reduce the risk of exploitation from attacks like Password Guessing.

entities.name: MULTI-FACTOR AUTHENTICATION
entities.description: Multi-factor Authentication is a security measure that requires two or more pieces of evidence for user authentication, enhancing security against Password Guessing.

entities.name: PASSWORD POLICIES
entities.description: Password Policies are guidelines set to enforce secure password practices for user accounts, aimed at preventing Password Guessing attacks.

entities.name: ACCOUNT USE POLICIES
entities.description: Account Use Policies involve configuring account features such as login attempt lockouts and specific login times to mitigate risks associated with Password Guessing.

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Windows Service. Their names are as follows:
* SILENTTRINITY
* PsExec
* PowerSploit
* Empire
* NightClub
* Industroyer
* FunnyDream
* Winnti for Windows
* Cuba
* Briba

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: SILENTTRINITY
Software description: [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework primarily written in Python that includes stagers written in Powershell, C, and Boo. [SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) was used in a 2019 campaign against Croatian government agencies by unidentified cyber actors.(Citation: GitHub SILENTTRINITY March 2022)(Citation: Security Affairs SILENTTRINITY July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PsExec
Software description: [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) is a free Microsoft tool that can be used to execute a program on another computer. It is used by IT administrators and attackers.(Citation: Russinovich Sysinternals)(Citation: SANS PsExec)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: NightClub
Software description: [NightClub](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1090) is a modular implant written in C++ that has been used by [MoustachedBouncer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1019) since at least 2014.(Citation: MoustachedBouncer ESET August 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Industroyer
Software description: [Industroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0604) is a sophisticated malware framework designed to cause an impact to the working processes of Industrial Control Systems (ICS), specifically components used in electrical substations.(Citation: ESET Industroyer) [Industroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0604) was used in the attacks on the Ukrainian power grid in December 2016.(Citation: Dragos Crashoverride 2017) This is the first publicly known malware specifically designed to target and impact operations in the electric grid.(Citation: Dragos Crashoverride 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FunnyDream
Software description: [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044) is a backdoor with multiple components that was used during the [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0007) campaign since at least 2019, primarily for execution and exfiltration.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Winnti for Windows
Software description: [Winnti for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) is a modular remote access Trojan (RAT) that has been used likely by multiple groups to carry out intrusions in various regions since at least 2010, including by one group referred to as the same name, [Winnti Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0044).(Citation: Kaspersky Winnti April 2013)(Citation: Microsoft Winnti Jan 2017)(Citation: Novetta Winnti April 2015)(Citation: 401 TRG Winnti Umbrella May 2018). The Linux variant is tracked separately under [Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430).(Citation: Chronicle Winnti for Linux May 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cuba
Software description: 
[Cuba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0625) is a Windows-based ransomware family that has been used against financial institutions, technology, and logistics organizations in North and South America as well as Europe since at least December 2019.(Citation: McAfee Cuba April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

  <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">PsExec is a free Microsoft tool that can be used to execute a program on another computer, utilized by IT administrators and attackers.</data>      <data key="d2">33bffe47b81822f307ab567ebe60294a</data>    </node>    <node id="POWERSPOILT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">PowerSploit is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of PowerShell modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing.</data>      <data key="d2">33bffe47b81822f307ab567ebe60294a</data>    </node>    <node id="EMPIRE">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Empire is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">NightClub is a modular implant written in C++ that has been used by MoustachedBouncer since at least 2014.</data>      <data key="d2">33bffe47b81822f307ab567ebe60294a</data>    </node>    <node id="INDUSTROYER">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Industroyer is a sophisticated malware framework </node>    <node id="FUNNYDREAM">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">FunnyDream is a backdoor with multiple components used during the FunnyDream campaign primarily for key="d1">Winnti for Windows is a modular remote access Trojan (RAT) used likely by multiple groups to carry out intrusions in various regions since at least 2010.</data>      <data key="d2">33bffe47b81822f307ab567ebe60294a</data>    </node>    <node id="CUBA">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Cuba is a Windows-based ransomware family that has been used Chronicle Winnti for Linux May 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cuba
Software description: 
[Cuba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0625) is a Windows-based ransomware family that has been used against financial institutions, technology, and logistics organizations in North and South America as well as Europe since at least December 2019.(Citation: McAfee Cuba April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Briba
Software description: [Briba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0204) is a trojan used by [Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) to open a backdoor and download files on to compromised hosts. (Citation: Symantec Elderwood Sept 2012) (Citation: Symantec Briba May 2012)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: CUBA
entities.description: Cuba is a ransomware family that targets financial institutions, technology, and logistics organizations in North and South America as well as Europe since at least December 2019.

entities.name: BRIBA
entities.description: Briba is a trojan used by Elderwood to open a backdoor and download files onto compromised hosts.

entities.name: ELDERWOOD
entities.description: Elderwood is a group associated with the use of the Briba trojan for cyber attacks.

entities.name: FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS
entities.description: Financial institutions are organizations that provide financial services, which have been targeted by the Cuba ransomware.

entities.name: TECHNOLOGY ORGANIZATIONS
entities.description: Technology organizations are companies involved in the development and application of technology, also targeted by the Cuba ransomware.

entities.name: LOGISTICS ORGANIZATIONS
entities.description: Logistics organizations are companies that manage the flow of goods and services, which have been affected by the Cuba ransomware.

entities.name: NORTH AMERICA
entities.description: North America is a continent that has been targeted by the Cuba ransomware family.

entities.name: SOUTH AMERICA
entities.description: South America is a continent that has been targeted by the Cuba ransomware family.

entities.name: EUROPE
entities.description: Europe is a continent that has been targeted by the Cuba ransomware family.

entities.name: DECEMBER 2019
entities.description: December 2019 marks the time when the Cuba ransomware family began its operations against various organizations.

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called External Remote Services. Their names are as follows:
* Network Segmentation 
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* Limit Access to Resource Over Network 
* Multi-factor Authentication 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Mitigation method description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.

Mitigation method name: Multi-factor Authentication
Mitigation method description: Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.

entities.name: NETWORK SEGMENTATION
entities.description: Network Segmentation is a mitigation method that involves architecting sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources to enhance security against attacks.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program is a mitigation method that focuses on removing or denying access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

entities.name: LIMIT ACCESS TO RESOURCE OVER NETWORK
entities.description: Limit Access to Resource Over Network is a mitigation method that aims to prevent access to file shares and unnecessary services to enhance network security.

entities.name: MULTI-FACTOR AUTHENTICATION
entities.description: Multi-factor Authentication is a mitigation method that requires two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system, enhancing security by adding layers of verification.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation Methods refer to strategies and techniques employed to reduce the risk of attacks, specifically against External Remote Services.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Match Legitimate Name or Location. Their names are as follows:
* PcShare
* Brute Ratel C4
* ShimRatReporter
* MCMD
* Misdat
* RainyDay
* MechaFlounder
* SLOTHFULMEDIA
* Elise
* OwaAuth

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: PcShare
Software description: [PcShare](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1050) is an open source remote access tool that has been modified and used by Chinese threat actors, most notably during the FunnyDream campaign since late 2018.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)(Citation: GitHub PcShare 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Brute Ratel C4
Software description: [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) is a commercial red-teaming and adversarial attack simulation tool that first appeared in December 2020. [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was specifically designed to avoid detection by endpoint detection and response (EDR) and antivirus (AV) capabilities, and deploys agents called badgers to enable arbitrary command execution for lateral movement, privilege escalation, and persistence. In September 2022, a cracked version of [Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) was leaked in the cybercriminal underground, leading to its use by threat actors.(Citation: Dark Vortex Brute Ratel C4)(Citation: Palo Alto Brute Ratel July 2022)(Citation: MDSec Brute Ratel August 2022)(Citation: SANS Brute Ratel October 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Black Basta October 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ShimRatReporter
Software description: [ShimRatReporter](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0445) is a tool used by suspected Chinese adversary [Mofang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0103) to automatically conduct initial discovery. The details from this discovery are used to customize follow-on payloads (such as [ShimRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0444)) as well as set up faux infrastructure which mimics the adversary's targets. [ShimRatReporter](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0445) has been used in campaigns targeting multiple countries and sectors including government, military, critical infrastructure, automobile, and weapons development.(Citation: FOX-IT May 2016 Mofang)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MCMD
Software description: [MCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0500) is a remote access tool that provides remote command shell capability used by [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074).(Citation: Secureworks MCMD July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Misdat
Software description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is a backdoor that was used in [Operation Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0016) from 2010 to 2011.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RainyDay
Software description: [RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) is a backdoor tool that has been used by [Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) since at least 2020.(Citation: Bitdefender Naikon April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MechaFlounder
Software description: [MechaFlounder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0459) is a python-based remote access tool (RAT) that has been used by [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087). The payload uses a combination of actor developed code and code snippets freely available online in development communities.(Citation: Unit 42 MechaFlounder March 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Software description: [SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) is a remote access Trojan written in C++ that has been used by an unidentified "sophisticated cyber actor" since at least January 2017.(Citation: CISA MAR SLOTHFULMEDIA October 2020)(Citation: Costin Raiu IAmTheKing October 2020) It has been used to target government organizations, defense contractors, universities, and energy companies in Russia, India, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Malaysia, Ukraine, and Eastern Europe.(Citation: USCYBERCOM SLOTHFULMEDIA October 2020)(Citation: Kaspersky IAmTheKing October 2020)  

In October 2020, Kaspersky Labs assessed [SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) is part of an activity cluster it refers to as "IAmTheKing".(Citation: Kaspersky IAmTheKing October 2020) ESET also noted code similarity between [SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) and droppers used by a group it refers to as "PowerPool".(Citation: ESET PowerPool

entities.name: PCSHARE
entities.description: PcShare is an open source remote access tool modified and used by Chinese threat actors during the FunnyDream campaign since late 2018.

entities.name: BRUTE RATEL C4
entities.description: Brute Ratel C4 is a commercial red-teaming and adversarial attack simulation tool designed to avoid detection by EDR and AV capabilities.

entities.name: SHIMRATREPORTER
entities.description: ShimRatReporter is a tool used by the suspected Chinese adversary Mofang to conduct initial discovery and customize follow-on payloads.

entities.name: MCMD
entities.description: MCMD is a remote access tool providing remote command shell capability used by Dragonfly 2.0.

entities.name: MISDAT
entities.description: Misdat is a backdoor used in Operation Dust Storm from 2010 to 2011.

entities.name: RAINYDAY
entities.description: RainyDay is a backdoor tool used by Naikon since at least 2020.

entities.name: MECHAFLOUNDER
entities.description: MechaFlounder is a python-based remote access tool used by APT39, combining actor-developed code and publicly available code snippets.

entities.name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
entities.description: SLOTHFULMEDIA is a remote access Trojan used by an unidentified sophisticated cyber actor since at least January 2017, targeting various organizations across multiple countries.

entities.name: NAIKON
entities.description: Naikon is a cyber threat group that has been using the RainyDay backdoor tool since at least 2020.

entities.name: MOFANG
entities.description: Mofang is a suspected Chinese adversary group that uses ShimRatReporter for initial discovery in cyber operations.

entities.name: OPERATION DUST STORM
entities.description: Operation Dust Storm was a cyber campaign during which the Misdat backdoor was utilized from 2010 to 2011.

Labs assessed [SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) is part of an activity cluster it refers to as "IAmTheKing".(Citation: Kaspersky IAmTheKing October 2020) ESET also noted code similarity between [SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) and droppers used by a group it refers to as "PowerPool".(Citation: ESET PowerPool Code October 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Elise
Software description: [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) is a custom backdoor Trojan that appears to be used exclusively by [Lotus Blossom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0030). It is part of a larger group of
tools referred to as LStudio, ST Group, and APT0LSTU. (Citation: Lotus Blossom Jun 2015)(Citation: Accenture Dragonfish Jan 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: OwaAuth
Software description: [OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) is a Web shell and credential stealer deployed to Microsoft Exchange servers that appears to be exclusively used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027). (Citation: Dell TG-3390)
Platforms: Windows
