entities.name: SUGARUSH
entities.description: SUGARUSH is a small custom backdoor that establishes a reverse shell over TCP to a hard coded C2 address, identified during analysis of UNC3890's campaign targeting Israeli companies.

entities.name: NKABUSE
entities.description: NKAbuse is a Go-based, multi-platform malware that abuses NKN technology for data exchange, functioning as a potent implant with flooder and backdoor capabilities.

entities.name: QAKBOT
entities.description: QakBot is a modular banking trojan used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007, evolving from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware.

entities.name: QUIETSIEVE
entities.description: QuietSieve is an information stealer used by Gamaredon Group since at least 2021.

entities.name: SYSUPDATE
entities.description: SysUpdate is a backdoor written in C++ used by Threat Group-3390 since at least 2020.

entities.name: DARKTORTILLA
entities.description: DarkTortilla is a highly configurable .NET-based crypter used to deliver various information stealers, RATs, and payloads.

entities.name: COBALT GROUP
entities.description: Cobalt Group is a cybercriminal group known for using various malware, including the More_eggs backdoor.

entities.name: FIN6
entities.description: FIN6 is a cybercriminal group that has been involved in various financial crimes and is known to use the More_eggs backdoor.

entities.name: KE3CHANG
entities.description: Ke3chang is a threat actor group that has been using C2 malware like Neoichor since at least 2019.

entities.name: UNC3890
entities.description: UNC3890 is a threat actor group that has targeted Israeli companies and was associated with the SUGARUSH backdoor.

entities.name: NKN
entities.description: NKN (New Kind of Network) is a technology that NKAbuse malware abuses for data exchange between peers.

entities.name: THREAT GROUP-3390
entities.description: Threat Group-3390 is a cybercriminal group known for using backdoors like SysUpdate.

entities.name: INFORMATION STEALERS

chunk:
5. [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) has been used to deliver popular information stealers, RATs, and payloads such as [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331), AsyncRat, [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336), RedLine, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154), and Metasploit.(Citation: Secureworks DarkTortilla Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Woody RAT
Software description:  [Woody RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1065) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that has been used since at least August 2021 against Russian organizations.(Citation: MalwareBytes WoodyRAT Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
There are 1 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Network Logon Script. Their names are as follows:
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: NETWORK LOGON SCRIPT
entities.description: Network Logon Script is an attack technique that can be mitigated through specific methods to enhance security.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that involves setting access permissions for directories and files to enhance security against unauthorized access.

entities.name: RESTRICT ACCESS
entities.description: Restrict access is a general term referring to the practice of limiting user permissions to enhance security measures.

entities.name: DIRECTORY AND FILE PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Directory and file permissions are settings that determine who can access and modify files and directories in a computer system.

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called NTFS File Attributes. Their names are as follows:
* esentutl
* Expand
* Regin
* Valak
* LoJax
* PowerDuke
* DEADEYE
* POWERSOURCE
* WastedLocker
* BitPaymer

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: esentutl
Software description: [esentutl](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0404) is a command-line tool that provides database utilities for the Windows Extensible Storage Engine.(Citation: Microsoft Esentutl)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Expand
Software description: [Expand](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0361) is a Windows utility used to expand one or more compressed CAB files.(Citation: Microsoft Expand Utility) It has been used by [BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) to decompress a CAB file into executable content.(Citation: Palo Alto Networks BBSRAT)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Regin
Software description: [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) is a malware platform that has targeted victims in a range of industries, including telecom, government, and financial institutions. Some [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) timestamps date back to 2003. (Citation: Kaspersky Regin)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Valak
Software description: [Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) is a multi-stage modular malware that can function as a standalone information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019 targeting enterprises in the US and Germany.(Citation: Cybereason Valak May 2020)(Citation: Unit 42 Valak July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LoJax
Software description: [LoJax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0397) is a UEFI rootkit used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) to persist remote access software on targeted systems.(Citation: ESET LoJax Sept 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PowerDuke
Software description: [PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) is a backdoor that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) in 2016. It has primarily been delivered through Microsoft Word or Excel attachments containing malicious macros. (Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DEADEYE
Software description: [DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) is a malware launcher that has been used by [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) since at least May 2021. [DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) has variants that can either embed a payload inside a compiled binary (DEADEYE.EMBED) or append it to the end of a file (DEADEYE.APPEND).(Citation: Mandiant APT41)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POWERSOURCE
Software description: [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) is a PowerShell backdoor that is a heavily obfuscated and modified version of the publicly available tool DNS_TXT_Pwnage. It was observed in February 2017 in spearphishing campaigns against personnel involved with United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filings at various organizations. The malware was delivered when macros were enabled by the victim and a VBS script was dropped. (Citation: FireEye FIN7 March 2017) (Citation: Cisco DNSMessenger March 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: WastedLocker
Software description: [WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) is a ransomware family attributed to [Indrik Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0119) that has been used since at least May 2020. [WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) has been used against a broad variety of sectors, including manufacturing, information technology, and media.(Citation: Symantec WastedLocker June 2020)(Citation: NCC Group WastedLocker June 2020)(Citation: Sentinel Labs WastedLocker July 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BitPaymer
Software description: [BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) is a ransomware variant first observed in August 2017 targeting hospitals in the U.K. [BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) uses a unique encryption key, ransom note, and contact information for each operation. [BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) has several indicators suggesting overlap with the [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) malware and is often delivered via [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384).(Citation: Crowdstrike Indrik November 2018)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: ESENTUTL
entities.description: Esentutl is a command-line tool that provides database utilities for the Windows Extensible Storage Engine.

entities.name: EXPAND
entities.description: Expand is a Windows utility used to expand one or more compressed CAB files.

entities.name: REGIN
entities.description: Regin is a malware platform that has targeted victims in a range of industries, including telecom, government, and financial institutions.

entities.name: VALAK
entities.description: Valak is a multi-stage modular malware that can function as a standalone information stealer or downloader.

entities.name: LOJAX
entities.description: LoJax is a UEFI rootkit used by APT28 to persist remote access software on targeted systems.

entities.name: POWERDUKE
entities.description: PowerDuke is a backdoor that was used by APT29 in 2016, primarily delivered through Microsoft Word or Excel attachments.

entities.name: DEADEYE
entities.description: DEADEYE is a malware launcher used by APT41 since at least May 2021, with variants that can embed or append payloads.

entities.name: POWERSOURCE
entities.description: POWERSOURCE is a PowerShell backdoor that is a heavily obfuscated version of the publicly available tool DNS_TXT_Pwnage.

entities.name: WASTEDLOCKER
entities.description: WastedLocker is a ransomware family attributed to Indrik Spider, used against various sectors since at least May 2020.

entities.name: BITPAYMER
entities.description: BitPaymer is a ransomware variant first observed in August 2017 targeting hospitals in the U.K.

chunk:
There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called System Firmware. Their names are as follows:
* Boot Integrity 
* Update Software 
* Privileged Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Boot Integrity
Mitigation method description: Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.

Mitigation method name: Update Software
Mitigation method description: Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.description: Boot Integrity is a mitigation method that uses secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.

entities.description: Update Software is a mitigation method that involves performing regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

chunk:
There are 7 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Adversary-in-the-Middle. Their names are as follows:
* Filter Network Traffic 
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Limit Access to Resource Over Network 
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* User Training 
* Network Intrusion Prevention 
* Network Segmentation 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Mitigation method description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

entities.name: ADVERSARY-IN-THE-MIDDLE
entities.description: Adversary-in-the-Middle is an attack technique that involves intercepting and altering communication between two parties without their knowledge.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Filter Network Traffic is a mitigation method that uses network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description:
Encrypt Sensitive Information is a specific mitigation method that involves using strong encryption to protect sensitive data from being intercepted during an Adversary-in-the-Middle attack.
Encrypt Sensitive Information is a mitigation method that protects sensitive information with strong encryption.

entities.name: LIMIT ACCESS TO RESOURCE OVER NETWORK
entities.description:
Limit Access to Resource Over Network is a specific mitigation method that restricts access to resources to prevent unauthorized access during an Adversary-in-the-Middle attack.
Limit Access to Resource Over Network is a mitigation method that prevents access to file shares and remote systems, using mechanisms like network concentrators and RDP gateways.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description:
Disable or Remove Feature or Program is a specific mitigation method that involves removing unnecessary software to reduce vulnerabilities that could be exploited in an Adversary-in-the-Middle attack.
Disable or Remove Feature or Program is a mitigation method that involves removing or denying access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description:
User Training is a mitigation method that educates users about access or manipulation attempts to reduce risks from social engineering and spearphishing.
User Training is a specific mitigation method that educates users on recognizing and avoiding tactics used in Adversary-in-the-Middle attacks.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description:
Network Intrusion Prevention is a mitigation method that uses intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.
Network Intrusion Prevention is a specific mitigation method that uses detection signatures to block malicious traffic associated with Adversary-in-the-Middle attacks.

entities.name: NETWORK SEGMENTATION
entities.description:
Network Segmentation is a specific mitigation method that involves creating isolated sections of a network to protect sensitive systems from Adversary-in-the-Middle attacks.
Network Segmentation is a mitigation method that involves architecting sections of the network to isolate critical systems and prevent access to sensitive information.

chunk:
There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Modify Cloud Compute Infrastructure. Their names are as follows:
* User Account Management 
* Audit 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that involves managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts to enhance security.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a mitigation method that involves performing audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, and configurations to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation Methods refer to strategies or techniques implemented to reduce the risk of attacks, specifically in the context of cloud computing security.

chunk:
There are 3 software using the attack technique called Path Interception by PATH Environment Variable. Their names are as follows:
* PowerSploit
* Empire
* DarkGate

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: DarkGate
Software description: [DarkGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1111) first emerged in 2018 and has evolved into an initial access and data gathering tool associated with various criminal cyber operations. Written in Delphi and named "DarkGate" by its author, [DarkGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1111) is associated with credential theft, cryptomining, cryptotheft, and pre-ransomware actions.(Citation: Ensilo Darkgate 2018) DarkGate use increased significantly starting in 2022 and is under active development by its author, who provides it as a Malware-as-a-Service offering.(Citation: Trellix Darkgate 2023)
Platforms: Windows

entities.description: Empire is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub, primarily written in Python with post-exploitation agents in PowerShell for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS.

entities.name: DARKGATE
entities.description: DarkGate is an initial access and data gathering tool associated with various criminal cyber operations, known for credential theft, cryptomining, cryptotheft, and pre-ransomware actions, and is provided as a Malware-as-a-Service offering.

entities.name: PATH ENVIRONMENT VARIABLE
entities.description: The PATH Environment Variable is a system variable that specifies a set of directories where executable programs are located, which can be exploited in attack techniques like Path Interception.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Shortcut Modification. Their names are as follows:
* Empire
* RogueRobin
* RedLeaves
* Okrum
* Reaver
* Grandoreiro
* Helminth
* MarkiRAT
* Micropsia
* SslMM

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: RogueRobin
Software description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) is a payload used by [DarkHydrus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079) that has been developed in PowerShell and C#. (Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RedLeaves
Software description: [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) is a malware family used by [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045). The code overlaps with [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) and may be based upon the open source tool Trochilus. (Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017) (Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Okrum
Software description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) is a Windows backdoor that has been seen in use since December 2016 with strong links to [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004).(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Reaver
Software description: [Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) is a malware family that has been in the wild since at least late 2016. Reporting indicates victims have primarily been associated with the "Five Poisons," which are movements the Chinese government considers dangerous. The type of malware is rare due to its final payload being in the form of [Control Panel](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218/002) items.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Grandoreiro
Software description: [Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) is a banking trojan written in Delphi that was first observed in 2016 and uses a Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) business model. [Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) has confirmed victims in Brazil, Mexico, Portugal, and Spain.(Citation: Securelist Brazilian Banking Malware July 2020)(Citation: ESET Grandoreiro April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Helminth
Software description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) is a backdoor that has at least two variants - one written in VBScript and PowerShell that is delivered via a macros in Excel spreadsheets, and one that is a standalone Windows executable. (Citation: Palo Alto OilRig May 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MarkiRAT
Software description: [MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652) is a remote access Trojan (RAT) compiled with Visual Studio that has been used by [Ferocious Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0137) since at least 2015.(Citation: Kaspersky Ferocious Kitten Jun 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Micropsia
Software description: [Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) is a remote access tool written in Delphi.(Citation: Talos Micropsia June 2017)(Citation: Radware Micropsia July 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SslMM
Software description: [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) is a full-featured backdoor used by [Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) that has multiple variants. (Citation: Baumgartner Naikon 2015)
Platforms: Windows

entities.description: Empire is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub, primarily written in Python with post-exploitation agents in PowerShell for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS.

entities.name: ROGUEROBIN
entities.description: RogueRobin is a payload developed in PowerShell and C# used by DarkHydrus.

entities.name: REDLEAVES
entities.description: RedLeaves is a malware family used by menuPass, overlapping with PlugX and possibly based on the open source tool Trochilus.

entities.name: OKRUM
entities.description: Okrum is a Windows backdoor linked to Ke3chang, in use since December 2016.

entities.name: REAVER
entities.description: Reaver is a malware family associated with the "Five Poisons" movements considered dangerous by the Chinese government, rare due to its payload being Control Panel items.

entities.name: GRANDOREIRO
entities.description: Grandoreiro is a banking trojan written in Delphi, first observed in 2016, using a Malware-as-a-Service model with confirmed victims in Brazil, Mexico, Portugal, and Spain.

entities.name: HELMINTH
entities.description: Helminth is a backdoor with variants in VBScript and PowerShell, delivered via Excel macros, and a standalone Windows executable.

entities.name: MARKIRAT
entities.description: MarkiRAT is a remote access Trojan used by Ferocious Kitten since at least 2015, compiled with Visual Studio.

entities.name: MICROPSIA
entities.description: Micropsia is a remote access tool written in Delphi.

entities.name: SSLMM
entities.description: SslMM is a full-featured backdoor used by Naikon, with multiple variants.

entities.name: MENUPASS
entities.description: menuPass is a threat group that uses the RedLeaves malware family in its attacks.

entities.name: KE3CHANG
entities.description: Ke3chang is a threat group associated with the Okrum backdoor, known for its cyber espionage activities.

entities.name: FIVE POISONS
entities.description: The Five Poisons refer to movements that the Chinese government considers dangerous, associated with the Reaver malware.

entities.name: FEROCIOUS KITTEN
entities.description: Ferocious Kitten is a threat group that has been using the MarkiRAT remote access Trojan since at least 2015.

entities.name: NAIKON
entities.description: Naikon is a threat group that utilizes the SslMM backdoor in its cyber operations.

chunk:
There are 4 software using the attack technique called Remote Email Collection. Their names are as follows:
* MailSniper
* LightNeuron
* SeaDuke
* Valak

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: MailSniper
Software description: MailSniper is a penetration testing tool for searching through email in a Microsoft Exchange environment for specific terms (passwords, insider intel, network architecture information, etc.). It can be used by a non-administrative user to search their own email, or by an Exchange administrator to search the mailboxes of every user in a domain.(Citation: GitHub MailSniper)
Platforms: Office 365, Windows, Azure AD

Software name: LightNeuron
Software description: [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) is a sophisticated backdoor that has targeted Microsoft Exchange servers since at least 2014. [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) to target diplomatic and foreign affairs-related organizations. The presence of certain strings in the malware suggests a Linux variant of [LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) exists.(Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: SeaDuke
Software description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2014 to 2015. It was used primarily as a secondary backdoor for victims that were already compromised with [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046). (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Valak
Software description: [Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) is a multi-stage modular malware that can function as a standalone information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019 targeting enterprises in the US and Germany.(Citation: Cybereason Valak May 2020)(Citation: Unit 42 Valak July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: MAILSNIPER
entities.description: MailSniper is a penetration testing tool designed for searching through email in a Microsoft Exchange environment for specific terms such as passwords and insider intel. It can be used by both non-administrative users and Exchange administrators to search mailboxes in a domain.

entities.name: LIGHTNEURON
entities.description: LightNeuron is a sophisticated backdoor targeting Microsoft Exchange servers, used by the Turla group to attack diplomatic and foreign affairs-related organizations since at least 2014. It may also have a Linux variant.

entities.name: SEADUKE
entities.description: SeaDuke is malware utilized by APT29 from 2014 to 2015, primarily serving as a secondary backdoor for victims already compromised with CozyCar.

entities.name: VALAK
entities.description: Valak is a multi-stage modular malware first observed in 2019, capable of functioning as an information stealer or downloader, targeting enterprises in the US and Germany.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber espionage group associated with the Russian government, known for using malware like SeaDuke in their operations.

entities.name: COZYCAR
entities.description: CozyCar is a malware tool that was used in conjunction with SeaDuke, indicating its role in cyber attacks conducted by APT29.

* Antivirus/Antimalware 
* Execution Prevention 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: Antivirus/Antimalware
Mitigation method description: Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

chunk:
There are 5 software using the attack technique called Boot or Logon Autostart Execution. Their names are as follows:
* xCaon
* Dtrack
* Mis-Type
* BoxCaon
* Misdat

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: xCaon
Software description: [xCaon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0653) is an HTTP variant of the [BoxCaon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0651) malware family that has used by [IndigoZebra](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0136) since at least 2014. [xCaon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0653) has been used to target political entities in Central Asia, including Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan.(Citation: Checkpoint IndigoZebra July 2021)(Citation: Securelist APT Trends Q2 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Dtrack
Software description: [Dtrack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0567) is spyware that was discovered in 2019 and has been used against Indian financial institutions, research facilities, and the Kudankulam Nuclear Power Plant. [Dtrack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0567) shares similarities with the DarkSeoul campaign, which was attributed to [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032). (Citation: Kaspersky Dtrack)(Citation: Securelist Dtrack)(Citation: Dragos WASSONITE)(Citation: CyberBit Dtrack)(Citation: ZDNet Dtrack)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Mis-Type
Software description: [Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) is a backdoor hybrid that was used in [Operation Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0016) by 2012.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BoxCaon
Software description: [BoxCaon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0651) is a Windows backdoor that was used by [IndigoZebra](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0136) in a 2021 spearphishing campaign against Afghan government officials. [BoxCaon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0651)'s name stems from similarities shared with the malware family [xCaon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0653).(Citation: Checkpoint IndigoZebra July 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Misdat
Software description: [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is a backdoor that was used in [Operation Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0016) from 2010 to 2011.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)
Platforms: Windows

entities.description: xCaon is an HTTP variant of the BoxCaon malware family used by IndigoZebra since at least 2014, targeting political entities in Central Asia, including Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan.

entities.name: DTRACK
entities.description: Dtrack is spyware discovered in 2019, used against Indian financial institutions, research facilities, and the Kudankulam Nuclear Power Plant, sharing similarities with the DarkSeoul campaign attributed to Lazarus Group.

entities.name: MIS-TYPE
entities.description: Mis-Type is a backdoor hybrid used in Operation Dust Storm by 2012.

entities.name: BOXCAON
entities.description: BoxCaon is a Windows backdoor used by IndigoZebra in a 2021 spearphishing campaign against Afghan government officials, sharing similarities with the xCaon malware.

entities.name: MISDAT
entities.description: Misdat is a backdoor used in Operation Dust Storm from 2010 to 2011.

entities.name: INDIGOZEBRA
entities.description: IndigoZebra is a group that has utilized various malware, including xCaon and BoxCaon, in cyber attacks targeting political entities and government officials.

entities.name: UZBEKISTAN
entities.description: Uzbekistan is a Central Asian country targeted by the xCaon malware.

entities.name: LAZARUS GROUP
entities.description: Lazarus Group is a cybercrime group attributed to various cyber attacks, including the DarkSeoul campaign related to Dtrack.

entities.name: KUDANKULAM NUCLEAR POWER PLANT
entities.description: The Kudankulam Nuclear Power Plant is an Indian facility targeted by the Dtrack spyware.

entities.name: OPERATION DUST STORM
entities.description: Operation Dust Storm is a cyber operation in which Mis-Type and Misdat were used.

Mitigation method name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

used to reduce the impact of security threats, such as the Time Providers attack technique.)<|COMPLETE|></data>      <data key="d2">9fa7031e50293a744eed49e2d76be239</data>    </node>    <edge source="RESTRICT REGISTRY PERMISSIONS" target="RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both are mitigation methods aimed at enhancing security against attack techniques like Time Providers</data>      <data key="d5">9fa7031e50293a744eed49e2d76be239</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called Standard Encoding. Their names are as follows:
* Sliver
* SideTwist
* Fysbis
* DnsSystem
* ADVSTORESHELL
* Flagpro
* Stuxnet
* SeaDuke
* SysUpdate
* Chaes

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Sliver
Software description: [Sliver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0633) is an open source, cross-platform, red team command and control framework written in Golang.(Citation: Bishop Fox Sliver Framework August 2019)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: SideTwist
Software description: [SideTwist](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0610) is a C-based backdoor that has been used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) since at least 2021.(Citation: Check Point APT34 April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Fysbis
Software description: [Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) is a Linux-based backdoor used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) that dates back to at least 2014.(Citation: Fysbis Palo Alto Analysis)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: DnsSystem
Software description: [DnsSystem](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1021) is a .NET based DNS backdoor, which is a customized version of the open source tool DIG.net, that has been used by [HEXANE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1001) since at least June 2022.(Citation: Zscaler Lyceum DnsSystem June 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ADVSTORESHELL
Software description: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) is a spying backdoor that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) from at least 2012 to 2016. It is generally used for long-term espionage and is deployed on targets deemed interesting after a reconnaissance phase. (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 2)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Flagpro
Software description: [Flagpro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0696) is a Windows-based, first-stage downloader that has been used by [BlackTech](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0098) since at least October 2020. It has primarily been used against defense, media, and communications companies in Japan.(Citation: NTT Security Flagpro new December 2021) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Stuxnet
Software description: [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was the first publicly reported piece of malware to specifically target industrial control systems devices. [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) is a large and complex piece of malware that utilized multiple different behaviors including multiple zero-day vulnerabilities, a sophisticated Windows rootkit, and network infection routines.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Chien February 2011)(Citation: CISA ICS Advisory ICSA-10-272-01)(Citation: ESET Stuxnet Under the Microscope)(Citation: Langer Stuxnet) [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was discovered in 2010, with some components being used as early as November 2008.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Chien February 2011) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SeaDuke
Software description: [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2014 to 2015. It was used primarily as a secondary backdoor for victims that were already compromised with [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046). (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SysUpdate
Software description: [SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) is a backdoor written in C++ that has been used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) since at least 2020.(Citation: Trend Micro Iron Tiger April 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: Chaes
Software description: [Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) is a multistage information stealer written in several programming languages that collects login credentials, credit card numbers, and other financial information. [Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) was first observed in 2020, and appears to primarily target victims in Brazil as well as other e-commerce customers in Latin America.(Citation: Cybereason Chaes Nov 2020)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: FYSBIS
entities.description: Fysbis is a Linux-based backdoor used by APT28 that dates back to at least 2014, showcasing its long-term use in cyber attacks.

entities.name: DNSSYSTEM
entities.description: DnsSystem is a .NET based DNS backdoor, a customized version of DIG.net, used by HEXANE since at least June 2022.

entities.name: ADVSTORESHELL
entities.description: ADVSTORESHELL is a spying backdoor used by APT28 from at least 2012 to 2016, primarily for long-term espionage.

entities.name: FLAGPRO
entities.description: Flagpro is a Windows-based downloader used by BlackTech since at least October 2020, targeting defense and media companies in Japan.

entities.name: STUXNET

entities.name: SEADUKE

entities.name: SYSUPDATE

entities.name: CHAES

entities.name: APT28
entities.description: APT28 is a well-known cyber espionage group that has utilized various malware, including Fysbis and ADVSTORESHELL, in its operations.

entities.name: HEXANE

entities.name: BLACKTECH

entities.name: APT29

chunk:
There are 10 software using the attack technique called JavaScript. Their names are as follows:
* Donut
* AppleSeed
* Cobalt Strike
* Metamorfo
* NanHaiShu
* QakBot
* Avaddon
* GRIFFON
* SocGholish
* EnvyScout

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Donut
Software description: [Donut](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0695) is an open source framework used to generate position-independent shellcode.(Citation: Donut Github)(Citation: Introducing Donut) [Donut](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0695) generated code has been used by multiple threat actors to inject and load malicious payloads into memory.(Citation: NCC Group WastedLocker June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: AppleSeed
Software description: [AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) is a backdoor that has been used by [Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) to target South Korean government, academic, and commercial  targets since at least 2021.(Citation: Malwarebytes Kimsuky June 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Android

Software name: Cobalt Strike
Software description: [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as “adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors”. Cobalt Strike’s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system.(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)

In addition to its own capabilities, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) leverages the capabilities of other well-known tools such as Metasploit and [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: Metamorfo
Software description: [Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) is a Latin-American banking trojan operated by a Brazilian cybercrime group that has been active since at least April 2018. The group focuses on targeting banks and cryptocurrency services in Brazil and Mexico.(Citation: Medium Metamorfo Apr 2020)(Citation: ESET Casbaneiro Oct 2019) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NanHaiShu
Software description: [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) is a remote access tool and JScript backdoor used by [Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065). [NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228) has been used to target government and private-sector organizations that have relations to the South China Sea dispute. (Citation: Proofpoint Leviathan Oct 2017) (Citation: fsecure NanHaiShu July 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: QakBot
Software description: [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is a modular banking trojan that has been used primarily by financially-motivated actors since at least 2007. [QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) is continuously maintained and developed and has evolved from an information stealer into a delivery agent for ransomware, most notably [ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) and [Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554).(Citation: Trend Micro Qakbot December 2020)(Citation: Red Canary Qbot)(Citation: Kaspersky QakBot September 2021)(Citation: ATT QakBot April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Avaddon
Software description: [Avaddon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0640) is ransomware written in C++ that has been offered as Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) since at least June 2020.(Citation: Awake Security Avaddon)(Citation: Arxiv Avaddon Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: GRIFFON
Software description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) is a JavaScript backdoor used by [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046). (Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SocGholish
Software description: [SocGholish](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1124) is a JavaScript-based loader malware that has been used since at least 2017. It has been observed in use against multiple sectors globally for initial access, primarily through drive-by-downloads masquerading as software updates. SocGholish is operated by [Mustard Tempest](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1020) and its access has been sold to groups including [Indrik Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0119) for downloading secondary RAT and ransomware payloads.(Citation: SentinelOne SocGholish Infrastructure November 2022)(Citation: SocGholish-update)(Citation: Red Canary SocG

chunk:
drive-by-downloads masquerading as software updates. SocGholish is operated by [Mustard Tempest](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1020) and its access has been sold to groups including [Indrik Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0119) for downloading secondary RAT and ransomware payloads.(Citation: SentinelOne SocGholish Infrastructure November 2022)(Citation: SocGholish-update)(Citation: Red Canary SocGholish March 2024)(Citation: Secureworks Gold Prelude Profile) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EnvyScout
Software description: [EnvyScout](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0634) is a dropper that has been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least 2021.(Citation: MSTIC Nobelium Toolset May 2021)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: SOCGHOLISH
entities.description: SocGholish is a malicious software operation that masquerades as software updates and is involved in drive-by downloads.

entities.name: MUSTARD TEMPEST
entities.description: Mustard Tempest is the group that operates SocGholish and is involved in cybercriminal activities.

entities.name: INDRIK SPIDER
entities.description: Indrik Spider is a group that has purchased access to SocGholish for the purpose of downloading secondary RAT and ransomware payloads.

entities.name: ENVYSCOUT
entities.description: EnvyScout is a dropper software used by APT29 since at least 2021, designed to facilitate the installation of other malicious software.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber espionage group that has been using EnvyScout as part of its toolset since at least 2021.

entities.name: SENTINELONE
entities.description: SentinelOne is a cybersecurity company that has reported on the SocGholish infrastructure and its activities.

entities.name: RED CANARY
entities.description: Red Canary is a cybersecurity firm that has provided insights into the SocGholish operation and its implications.

entities.name: SECUREWORKS
entities.description: Secureworks is a cybersecurity company that has profiled the Gold Prelude group, which is related to the SocGholish operation.

entities.name: GOLD PRELUDE
entities.description: Gold Prelude is a cyber threat group that has been associated with the activities of SocGholish and other malicious software.

Software name: ROADTools
Software description: [ROADTools](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0684) is a framework for enumerating Azure Active Directory environments. The tool is written in Python and publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: ROADtools Github)
Platforms: None

Software name: AADInternals
Software description: [AADInternals](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0677) is a PowerShell-based framework for administering, enumerating, and exploiting Azure Active Directory. The tool is publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: AADInternals Github)(Citation: AADInternals Documentation)
Platforms: Windows, Azure AD, Office 365

Software name: Pacu
Software description: Pacu is an open-source AWS exploitation framework. The tool is written in Python and publicly available on GitHub.(Citation: GitHub Pacu)
Platforms: IaaS

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Compromise Software Dependencies and Development Tools. Their names are as follows:
* Limit Software Installation 
* Vulnerability Scanning 
* Update Software 
* Application Developer Guidance 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Limit Software Installation
Mitigation method description: Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

Mitigation method name: Vulnerability Scanning
Mitigation method description: Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.

Mitigation method name: Update Software
Mitigation method description: Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

Mitigation method name: Application Developer Guidance
Mitigation method description: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.

entities.name: LIMIT SOFTWARE INSTALLATION
entities.description: Limit Software Installation is a mitigation method that blocks users or groups from installing unapproved software.

entities.name: VULNERABILITY SCANNING
entities.description: Vulnerability Scanning is a method used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.

entities.name: UPDATE SOFTWARE
entities.description: Update Software is a mitigation method that involves performing regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

entities.name: APPLICATION DEVELOPER GUIDANCE
entities.description: Application Developer Guidance is a mitigation method that provides guidance or training to application developers to avoid introducing security weaknesses.

entities.name: COMPROMISE SOFTWARE DEPENDENCIES AND DEVELOPMENT TOOLS
entities.description: Compromise Software Dependencies and Development Tools is an attack technique that targets software dependencies and development tools to exploit vulnerabilities.

chunk:
There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Bootkit. Their names are as follows:
* Boot Integrity 
* Privileged Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Boot Integrity
Mitigation method description: Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

chunk:
There are 1 software using the attack technique called Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts. Their names are as follows:
* RotaJakiro

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: RotaJakiro
Software description: [RotaJakiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1078) is a 64-bit Linux backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050). First seen in 2018, it uses a plugin architecture to extend capabilities. [RotaJakiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1078) can determine it's permission level and execute according to access type (`root` or `user`).(Citation: RotaJakiro 2021 netlab360 analysis)(Citation: netlab360 rotajakiro vs oceanlotus)
Platforms: Linux

entities.name: ROTAJAKIRO
entities.description: RotaJakiro is a 64-bit Linux backdoor used by APT32, first seen in 2018, utilizing a plugin architecture to extend its capabilities and determine permission levels for execution.

entities.name: APT32
entities.description: APT32 is a hacking group associated with the use of RotaJakiro, known for its cyber espionage activities.

entities.name: SOFTWARE
entities.description: Software refers to the collection of programs and operating information used by computers, including RotaJakiro as a specific example.

chunk:
There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Dynamic Data Exchange. Their names are as follows:
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 
* Application Isolation and Sandboxing 
* Software Configuration 
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: Application Isolation and Sandboxing
Mitigation method description: Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.

Mitigation method name: Software Configuration
Mitigation method description: Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

entities.name: DYNAMIC DATA EXCHANGE
entities.description: Dynamic Data Exchange is an attack technique that can be mitigated through various methods to prevent security risks.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that uses capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems.

entities.name: APPLICATION ISOLATION AND SANDBOXING
entities.description: Application Isolation and Sandboxing is a mitigation method that restricts execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.

entities.name: SOFTWARE CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Software Configuration is a mitigation method that implements configuration changes to software to mitigate security risks associated with its operation.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program is a mitigation method that removes or denies access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

entities.name: SUSPICIOUS BEHAVIOR PATTERNS
entities.description: Suspicious behavior patterns are actions that may indicate a security threat, which can be prevented through various mitigation methods.

entities.name: VIRTUAL ENVIRONMENT
entities.description: A virtual environment is a simulated computing environment that allows for the execution of code in isolation from the main system.

entities.name: SECURITY RISKS
entities.description: Security risks are potential threats that can exploit vulnerabilities in software or systems, necessitating mitigation methods.

entities.name: UNNECESSARY SOFTWARE
entities.description: Unnecessary software refers to programs that are not essential for operations and may pose security vulnerabilities if left accessible.

Mitigation method name: ***

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: RC SCRIPTS
entities.description: RC Scripts is an attack technique that requires mitigation methods to prevent unauthorized access and exploitation.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that involves setting access permissions for files and directories to enhance security.

entities.name: FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: File and Directory Permissions refer to the settings that control access to files and directories in a computer system, which can be restricted to enhance security.

Software name: PITSTOP
Software description: [PITSTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1123) is a backdoor that was deployed on compromised Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs during [Cutting Edge](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0029) to enable command execution and file read/write.(Citation: Mandiant Cutting Edge Part 3 February 2024)
Platforms: Network

Software name: Penquin
Software description: [Penquin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0587) is a remote access trojan (RAT) with multiple versions used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) to target Linux systems since at least 2014.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Penquin December 2014)(Citation: Leonardo Turla Penquin May 2020)
Platforms: Linux

chunk:
There are 4 software using the attack technique called Logon Script (Windows). Their names are as follows:
* Attor
* JHUHUGIT
* KGH_SPY
* Zebrocy

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Attor
Software description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) is a Windows-based espionage platform that has been seen in use since 2013. [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has a loadable plugin architecture to customize functionality for specific targets.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: JHUHUGIT
Software description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) is malware used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It is based on Carberp source code and serves as reconnaissance malware. (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy) (Citation: F-Secure Sofacy 2015) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KGH_SPY
Software description: [KGH_SPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0526) is a modular suite of tools used by [Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) for reconnaissance, information stealing, and backdoor capabilities. [KGH_SPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0526) derived its name from PDB paths and internal names found in samples containing "KGH".(Citation: Cybereason Kimsuky November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Zebrocy
Software description: [Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) is a Trojan that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) since at least November 2015. The malware comes in several programming language variants, including C++, Delphi, AutoIt, C#, VB.NET, and Golang. (Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)(Citation: CISA Zebrocy Oct 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

chunk: There are 9 software using the attack technique called Launch Daemon. Their names are as follows: * Green Lambert * COATHANGER * ThiefQuest * LoudMiner * OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D * Bundlore * Dacls * XCSSET * AppleJeus The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows: Software name: *** Software description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates. Software name: Green Lambert Software description: [Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) is a modular backdoor that security researchers assess has been used by an advanced threat group referred to as Longhorn and The Lamberts. First reported in 2017, the Windows variant of [Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) may have been used as early as 2008; a macOS version was uploaded to a multiscanner service in September 2014.(Citation: Kaspersky Lamberts Toolkit April 2017)(Citation: Objective See Green Lambert for OSX Oct 2021) Platforms: Windows, iOS, macOS, Linux Software name: COATHANGER Software description: [COATHANGER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1105) is a remote access tool (RAT) targeting FortiGate networking appliances. First used in 2023 in targeted intrusions against military and government entities in the Netherlands along with other victims, [COATHANGER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1105) was disclosed in early 2024, with a high confidence assessment linking this malware to a state-sponsored entity in the People's Republic of China. [COATHANGER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1105) is delivered after gaining access to a FortiGate device, with in-the-wild observations linked to exploitation of CVE-2022-42475. The name [COATHANGER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1105) is based on a unique string in the malware used to encrypt configuration files on disk: “She took his coat and hung it up”.(Citation: NCSC-NL COATHANGER Feb 2024) Platforms: Linux, Network Software name: ThiefQuest Software description: [ThiefQuest](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0595) is a virus, data stealer, and wiper that presents itself as ransomware targeting macOS systems. [ThiefQuest](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0595) was first seen in 2020 distributed via trojanized pirated versions of popular macOS software on Russian forums sharing torrent links.(Citation: Reed thiefquest fake ransom) Even though [ThiefQuest](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0595) presents itself as ransomware, since the dynamically generated encryption key is never sent to the attacker it may be more appropriately thought of as a form of wiper malware.(Citation: wardle evilquest partii)(Citation: reed thiefquest ransomware analysis) Platforms: macOS Software name: LoudMiner Software description: [LoudMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0451) is a cryptocurrency miner which uses virtualization software to siphon system resources. The miner has been bundled with pirated copies of Virtual Studio Technology (VST) for Windows and macOS.(Citation: ESET LoudMiner June 2019) Platforms: macOS, Windows Software name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D Software description: [OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) is a macOS backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050). First discovered in 2015, [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has continued to make improvements using a plugin architecture to extend capabilities, specifically using `.dylib` files. [OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) can also determine it's permission level and execute according to access type (`root` or `user`).(Citation: Unit42 OceanLotus 2017)(Citation: TrendMicro MacOS April 2018)(Citation: Trend Micro MacOS Backdoor November 2020) Platforms: macOS Software name: Bundlore Software description: [Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482) is adware written for macOS that has been in use since at least 2015. Though categorized as adware, [Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482) has many features associated with more traditional backdoors.(Citation: MacKeeper Bundlore Apr 2019) Platforms: macOS Software name: Dacls Software description: [Dacls](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0497) is a multi-platform remote access tool used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) since at least December 2019.(Citation: TrendMicro macOS Dacls May 2020)(Citation: SentinelOne Lazarus macOS July 2020) Platforms: macOS, Linux, Windows Software name: XCSSET Software description: [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) is a macOS modular backdoor that targets Xcode application developers. [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) was first observed in August 2020 and has been used to install a backdoor component, modify browser applications, conduct collection, and provide ransomware-like encryption capabilities.(

entities.description: Green Lambert is a modular backdoor used by an advanced threat group referred to as Longhorn and The Lamberts, first reported in 2017, with a Windows variant possibly used as early as 2008 and a macOS version uploaded in 2014.

entities.name: COATHANGER

entities.name: THIEFQUEST
entities.description: ThiefQuest is a virus, data stealer, and wiper that presents itself as ransomware targeting macOS systems, first seen in 2020.

entities.name: LOUDMINER
entities.description: LoudMiner is a cryptocurrency miner that uses virtualization software to siphon system resources, bundled with pirated copies of Virtual Studio Technology for Windows and macOS.

entities.name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
entities.description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D is a macOS backdoor used by APT32, first discovered in 2015, with capabilities extended through a plugin architecture.

entities.name: BUNDLORE
entities.description: Bundlore is adware for macOS that has been in use since at least 2015, featuring many characteristics of traditional backdoors.

entities.name: DACLS
entities.description: Dacls is a multi-platform remote access tool used by the Lazarus Group since at least December 2019.

entities.name: XCSSET
entities.description: XCSSET is a macOS modular backdoor targeting Xcode application developers, first observed in August 2020.

entities.name: PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA
entities.description: The People's Republic of China is a country linked to the state-sponsored entity responsible for the COATHANGER malware.

entities.name: LAZARUS GROUP
entities.description: Lazarus Group is a known cyber threat actor that utilizes the Dacls remote access tool.

entities.name: APT32
entities.description: APT32 is a cyber threat group that employs the OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D backdoor.

entities.description: macOS is an operating system targeted by various malware including ThiefQuest, LoudMiner, Bundlore, and XCSSET.)<|COMPLETE|>

id="GREEN LAMBERT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Green Lambert is a modular backdoor used by an advanced threat group referred to as Longhorn and The Lamberts, first reported in 2017, with a Windows variant possibly used as early as 2008 and a macOS version uploaded in 2014.</data>      <data key="d2">bcf2d4bbf4ba790ab09ff555317601eb</data>    </node>    <node id="COATHANGER">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">COATHANGER is a remote access tool targeting FortiGate networking appliances, first used in 2023 against military and government entities in the Netherlands, linked to a state-sponsored entity in China.</data>      <data key="d2">bcf2d4bbf4ba790ab09ff555317601eb</data>    </node>    <node id="THIEFQUEST">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">ThiefQuest is a virus, data stealer, and wiper that presents itself as ransomware targeting macOS systems, first seen in 2020.</data>      <data key="d2">bcf2d4bbf4ba790ab09ff555317601eb</data>    </node>    <node id="LOUDMINER">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">LoudMiner is a cryptocurrency miner that uses virtualization software to siphon system resources, bundled with pirated copies of Virtual Studio Technology for Windows and macOS.</data>      <data key="d2">bcf2d4bbf4ba790ab09ff555317601eb</data>    </node>    <node id="OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D is a macOS backdoor used by APT32, first discovered in 2015, with capabilities extended through a plugin architecture.</data>      <data key="d2">bcf2d4bbf4ba790ab09ff555317601eb</data>    </node>    <node id="BUNDLORE">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Bundlore is adware for macOS that has been in use since at least 2015, featuring many characteristics of traditional backdoors.</data>      <data key="d2">bcf2d4bbf4ba790ab09ff555317601eb</data>    </node>    <node id="DACLS">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Dacls is a multi-platform remote access tool used by the Lazarus Group since at least December 2019.</data>      <data key="d2">bcf2d4bbf4ba790ab09ff555317601eb</data>    </node>    <node id="XCSSET">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">XCSSET is a macOS modular backdoor targeting Xcode application developers, first observed in August 2020.</data>      <data key="d2">bcf2d4bbf4ba790ab09ff555317601eb</data>    </node>    <node id="LONGHORN">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">bcf2d4bbf4ba790ab09ff555317601eb</data>    </node>    <node id="PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">The People's Republic of China is a country linked to the state-sponsored entity responsible for the COATHANGER malware.</data>      <data key="d2">bcf2d4bbf4ba790ab09ff555317601eb</data>      <data key="d3">GEO</data>    </node>    <node id="LAZARUS GROUP">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">Lazarus Group is a known cyber threat actor that utilizes the Dacls remote access tool.</data>      <data key="d2">bcf2d4bbf4ba790ab09ff555317601eb</data>      <data key="d3">ORGANIZATION</data>    </node>    <node id="APT32">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">APT32 is a cyber threat group that employs the OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D backdoor.</data>      <data key="d2">bcf2d4bbf4ba790ab09ff555317601eb</data>      <data chunk:
2020)
Platforms: macOS, Linux, Windows

Software name: XCSSET
Software description: [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) is a macOS modular backdoor that targets Xcode application developers. [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) was first observed in August 2020 and has been used to install a backdoor component, modify browser applications, conduct collection, and provide ransomware-like encryption capabilities.(Citation: trendmicro xcsset xcode project 2020)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: AppleJeus
Software description: [AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) is a family of downloaders initially discovered in 2018 embedded within trojanized cryptocurrency applications. [AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032), targeting companies in the energy, finance, government, industry, technology, and telecommunications sectors, and several countries including the United States, United Kingdom, South Korea, Australia, Brazil, New Zealand, and Russia. [AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) has been used to distribute the [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) RAT.(Citation: CISA AppleJeus Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows, macOS

There are 1 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Archive via Utility. Their names are as follows:
* Audit 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a mitigation method that involves performing audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, and insecure configurations to identify potential weaknesses.

entities.name: ARCHIVE VIA UTILITY
entities.description: Archive via Utility is an attack technique that exploits vulnerabilities in systems to gain unauthorized access or perform malicious actions.

entities.name: SYSTEMS
entities.description: Systems refer to the various computer systems and networks that may be vulnerable to attacks and require mitigation methods to secure them.

entities.name: PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Permissions are the access rights granted to users or systems that determine what actions they can perform on a system or network.

entities.name: INSECURE SOFTWARE
entities.description: Insecure software refers to applications or programs that have vulnerabilities that can be exploited by attackers.

entities.name: INSECURE CONFIGURATIONS
entities.description: Insecure configurations are settings or configurations in systems that may expose them to security risks and vulnerabilities.
